Really fun game to play with friends! I played for only 3 hours so far but that was in one sitting. I will definitely keep playing this with my friends!
El juego esta bueno PERO PORFAVOR ME ESTOY QUEMANDO LAS MANOS OPTIMIZEN ESTO AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
bad stability and terrible progression. gacha games somehow have better models than this.

Don't play this trash unless you're a masochist who likes to struggle with the absolutely terrible gunplay and weapons. Literally the most inaccurate garbage guns of any game I've ever played. There's not a single gun that's *satisfying* to use. It also takes half a clip to kill one enemy, even if you don't miss any shots. I've literally seen two people stand 10 ft from one another and empty entire clips and not kill one another, the guns are that weak and inaccurate.

If you like Halo you'll probably like this but I have not had fun with it. It's pretty much just Halo multiplayer from any of the other Halo games but you'll most likely only ever play CtF as of right now. It controls decently well but still feels a bit clunky to me. Graphically it's pretty good but I don't think it's anything to write home about there either. Honestly just not the game for me like most of the other Halo games but I wanted to try this one because it's free and my friends have been playing. Also goodluck progressing in the game.
Love the game. needs to work out a few bugs. every now and then does crash though
I'm calling about your Warthog's extended warranty...

Honestly the worst XP system of any game I can think of. 32 kills 5 deaths, sorry you didn't get 5 pistols kills so no xp for you. Can't just play to have fun, feel like you have to chase arbitrary MMO task to gain XP and unlock new items. Not sure if its the botched netcode matched with forced crossplay but the servers are super laggy. Can't choose gamemodes and you are stuck with crossplay. Lets not even talk about the shitty sound design, someone behind you, cant hear them, someone shooting you from more than 10ft away, cant hear it. A great game to play with the buds but that is about it.

A few tips for the devs...  - More XP after each match, takes too long to level up. - Oddball should kill in one melee hit, it's been that way for decades. - Primary & secondary armor color should return. - Get rid of battlepass, no question about it.
Takes me back to 2008 playing Halo 3 in the dorms. Feels like good ol Halo!!
Tons of fun, slightly buggy. Would really like an option to select which gamemodes to queue for in quick play, but I expect it will come in future updates. The game just launched and feels great

The game is good enough, having played the Insider Flight quite a bit on top of this. Gameplay-wise, it's fairly fun and does enough to feel fresher compared to the Halos of yesteryear while not straying too much from the originals. The old artstyle returning, for example, was a good choice for keeping the ol' Halo feel that people complained about with H4 and H5. The weapons are cool, and there's enough of em to go around so you're not always stuck with AR and pistol.   While potentially on the more controversial side, I [i] do [/i] believe the new movement mechanics are better for the game in the long run. It makes it feel more modern, and while some people love the classic floaty movement, it just wouldn't feel very good in what's supposed to be a next-gen title. It's unfortunate, but the next step forward. I would like to hear some others' thoughts on this though, so do let me know your reasoning for if you prefer floaty movement.  My only real complaint is the new customization. I suppose it makes sense for a F2P game, but come on. A battle pass? Shaders I could tolerate, but there isn't even a way to get credits in-game without real-world money yet. You have to be clinically insane to think I'd spend ten bucks on a reshade. I don't even play battle royales, but at least those give you a cosmetic that looks good. The battle pass is a huge shame too. Like, I genuinely hope buying the campaign gives you the battle pass for good, because I will not spend 10 bucks every fucking time another one comes out. Doesn't help that they don't give you much in way of armor.  Yeah, that's about it. The game is fun, play it if you want, but if you're fully F2P, expect jack in cosmetics.
THEY DID IT FINALLY SWAT HAPPEN WOIW GREAT GAME 4/1

Not a lot of customization as advertised. even with battlepass season 1  very fun though, gameplay is tight. but greedy 343 ruins the game.  Also the launch is completely fucked up, and even decade old halos had better MIDNIGHT launches. I can no longer recommend this game due to 343's utter incompetence.
The game is great, just a few bugs of randomly crashing or sudden drops of FPS. Overall I love the Halo series and how they changed over the years.
go locked out of account with in 4 hours :)
Free ! Fun ! ... Love This, Big Thumbs Up

Absolutely unacceptable launch for a main series halo title. 343 yet again rises to desecrate the corpse of a respected franchise with paid cosmetics and no game to back itself up. there are 7 helmets at launch in a HALO game. 2 of which can be obtained without PAYING MONEY IN A HALO GAME. the matchmaking system consists of quickplay, ranked, and big team battle. so if you want to play or avoid a particular gamemode you can go play something else. there are 10 maps on launch. Halo 3 which released in 2008, 13 years ago, has twenty-four maps. all of the maps I've played so far are basic 3 lane maps, and also are incredibly small. even the outdoor maps feel tight and claustrophobic by series standards. God forbid any position on the map have meaningful sightlines. these seem like only a few reasons to dislike the game but that's all we've been given. a small selection of maps that don't support the gameplay, a quickplay button with no filters, and character customization that's been gutted from previous titles so it can be sold back to us at a premium. Don't waste your hard-drive space, and get a refund on your pre-order for the campaign.

If you wanna play halo; play the Master Chief Collection because this game is just a knockoff Call of Duty with halo textures slapped on top.  You can buy the cosmetic skins which you used to be able to unlock for free in all the older halos for 20 bucks a pop in infinite or you can buy Master Chief Collection for 20 bucks and unlock all of the same skins for free. Plus MCC provides you with all of the halo games to play AND their campaigns with multiplayer too.

Would rather just pay for the game to avoid this microtransaction nonsense. A shame that the monetization scheme is as bad as it is since everything looks very good (aside from the absolutely jarring inclusion of esports skins). I may have been able to tolerate the battlepass system, but having a storefront in which there are armor sets that cost $20 is ridiculous.

On top of mediocre gunplay, the progression system is unfathomably tedious, the cosmetics cost a third as much as a full service triple A game and the customization generally is just bad. If I have any additional hours past this post it's because I wanted to do something with friends. "Good with friends" isn't indicative of a good multiplayer game. It means that despite how bad the game is, I can still have fun playing an FPS with friends.

To begin, this is the most cohesive and stable AAA Multiplayer FPS release from a developer in years.   (Right Now) it's a free to play multiplayer with a battle pass system, 3 Big Team Battle maps, and 5 Quick Play Maps. In order to keep you playing, they have purposely made the challenges RNG based, and have made the matchmaking RNG based as well, as you can't choose the game modes you want to play, so you're likely to queue for multiple matches before even having the opportunity to complete a challenge. That is also RNG based however, as it's like waiting for the 'Hero Powerup' in Battlefront (2015).  Shouldn't this be negative? Overwhelmingly so? It's very draining, as it's your only form of progression, but the core game is great. The audio, the feedback, the gun play is all fun. The customization clearly has potential, and since the game seems to be performing well, it's likely that adjustments will be made to the progression and customization (as they've already made temporary adjustments) in order to accommodate what the fans want. This is a 'beta', so things are going to be added and changed, but what should be known is that the fixes are simple and they'll be done in time.   The game is fun, it is likely to continue being fun, the developers are making the right changes, and it's a multiplayer game where skill and creativity is rewarded in a sandbox environment. This feels like the progression of a franchise that has been respected thoroughly, and it really is. Besides some of the obvious annoyances, it'll be fixed and it's great to play with friends and feel like you're returning to classic multiplayer days.

Plays about as good as any other free to play game, this is not AAA gameplay. Its evolving, just backwards.  NOBODY PLAYS OBJECTIVE. Which might not be so bad but there is nothing gain by playing odd ball like slayer. Even in ranked.  Looks AAA visually, does not play like AAA. The classic guns aren't too bad besides the BR and Sniper. But every new gun is just bad. They are neat but its like 343 were too afraid to go all in so they just ended up half baked and practically unusable.  Multiplayers gameplay being bad is just the tip though. There is no progression system and only the battle pass. Leveling up the pass might be the worst part because as of now you only get 50xp for a match, no more no less unless you do a very specific weekly challenge which you have to go to a different gamemode to get. Most items(at least those worth getting) are locked behind a $10 pay wall. The credits to unlock it cannot be gained buy playing the game and has to be bought. You can just buy the whole battle pass for only over $200 for just season 1 or about 2000 games played roughly.  The multiplayer is just bad right now. Every gun beside the AR and rockets are awful or just don't feel right, doesn't feel good to use. After every match you have to go through 3 menus just to start another match, there is no auto play. There is NO PREGAME LOBBY and no post game lobby, where is the social aspect at? U.I. and menus are just a mess to use. When you're in game you can't mute people or block them using the scoreboard. Time to Kill in Infinite is the highest in the series or the guns are the weakest. Certain gamemodes should not have certain maps like Launch Site and One Flag or Behemoth and any gamemode. Behemoth is just terrible.  Visuals and Art Design : 10/10 : Best looking Halo in a decade  Gameplay : 3/10 : Gun-play and map layout are far from the best  Game Sound : 8/10 : It sounds really good beside the needler and warthog. Gun fire is also weird from a third person.  Soundtrack : IDK : It only ever uses one sound track that sounds like Cod and it got real annoying so its muted.  : Maybe Fixes : ¬∑ Put in a Reach like progression system and customization like 2021 MCC (If anything please do this one) ¬∑ Simplify the menus, it should be like two menus in from the main screen. (Its SUPER tedious to customize things) ¬∑ Reduce player health or shield (Yeah I've played the others, TTK is way too high in this game) ¬∑ Add in player collision for both enemys and allys (Without collision melee is messed up) ¬∑ Slightly increase melee range (Its really short for Halo) ¬∑ Shotgun, Banshee Bomb, Odd Ball, Heatwave need one shot potential (These have been a staple from the beginning) ¬∑ Plasma weapons need slightly higher tracking, they are too slow to hit often (the projectiles are too slow, easy to dodge) ¬∑ Put ricochet back to the sniper (Why remove this?) ¬∑ Every weapon but the AR needs a rework or tweaked (how about 15 round capacity for the pistol instead of 12)  I love Halo and want it to succeed but nothing has really changed since the flight two months ago. You guys finally locked down the visuals but now the gameplay is failing.

Overall, I enjoyed this game and I recommend it to those who played the Little Nightmares games. I wouldn't say this game competes with Little Nightmares in any way, but it's pretty hard to play this game and not acknowledge their similarity (and so I will).  Bramble: the Mountain King (BTMK) has upwards of 18 chapters, although it feels more like 14. Each chapter is brief, but they're completely unique and almost each features a "boss fight" of some kind. The game can be beaten in around 5 - 6 hours, and I beat it in 9 hours after getting 100% achievements and writing an achievement guide (check it out!) simultaneously. For this reason, I would say the game is overpriced and more of a $20 game, but I'm not complaining.   The art direction is good. The character design and the environment design are great, but the mythology is what makes this game stand out. Each character in BTMK is based off of Nordic fables, and the acts they carry out are dark and demented. Despite encountering the characters only briefly, they are what makes each chapter so memorable. Their tie-in to the main story is fitting, and it's impressive how many meaningful characters you experience in such a short time. Compared to the Little Nightmares games, there isn't really any guessing that has to be done for you to understand what's going on. This is nice, but when you finish the game, there isn't really more for you to do. There's no reason to go look up a lore breakdown or start a discussion why characters behave the way they do because, well, there isn't really any mystery. One thing I really loved about Little Nightmares were the metaphors the designers placed throughout each level, and how they helped foreshadow the story. To put it bluntly, BTMK just lacks that level of depth.  From an achievement hunting perspective, this game is very, very accessible although not particularly fun. The majority of achievements are for collecting figurines, so I wouldn't say the achievement hunting experience adds anything to the story of the game. Some are creative, but if you're looking for another "perfect" game to add to your steam profile ‚Äî this is an easier pick. However, once achievement is to beat the game without dying (which I hate). I personally don't see a replay-ability in this game, so this achievement is a huge chore.   All in all, fun game, worth a buy, but consider wishlisting it until there's a sale.

[b] Bramble: The Mountain King [/b] is a fantastic atmospheric platformer set in a world filled with dark and twisted Nordic horror folklore. This game is very immersive, has beautiful environments with interesting creature design, some unsettling horrific sequences, a wonderful soundtrack and a forgiving checkpoint system (you can only can get hit once and then have to start all over). The boss encounters are very unique and has some interesting mechanics thrown in. The story can be completed between 4 to 6 hours which includes searching for hidden figurines to be collected in each chapter.  The only negatives would be the janky controls, slow character movement speed and forced camera angles. Other then that, the overall experience was enjoyable especially during the platforming sections and boss encounters. For those of you who loved [b]Little Nightmares 1 and 2[/b], I would not hesitate to purchase this title. [9/10]

Huge disappointment.  Honestly, there is not a single moment/scene/puzzle I haven't seen in other games. The mini character in a overwhelmed large world? Try Unravel, a great puzzle-platform developed by Coldwood Interactive and published by EA. Get help from a giant? Try Brothers: A Tale of Two Sons released in 2013 by Starbreeze Studios, the latter has a similar story but far better execution and more interesting interactions.  What kept me playing till the end is the pure curiosity to see the fate of the boy. It doesn't change the fact that the scenery, the fight and the puzzles are all too basic and I get bored fast, there are few to look at and most look crude, which brings no excitement and even the disturbing monsters give a dry feeling, especially when their attacks are too simple, repeated and predictable. I finished the game in 3.5 hours, if not for the extremely slow walking speed and odds jump direction mechanic, otherwise it should be less than 3 hours.   Honestly I can't think of any highlights. Most puzzles are: Open a drawer to find a key to leave the house (if you call it a puzzle), chase creatures into sheepfold, find hidden gnomes, figure out a path in total darkness with zombies. Fight: Use sling shout on boss, but first shoot fixed targets and avoid repeated attacks, and then repeat. The only thing amused me might be the Hedgehog riding for 30 seconds. For the scenery, A big tree with hanged villagers and people being pinned by cross might be unique, but actually they are hardly not be seen in many games: Divinity: Original Sin, CoD, A Plague Tail... The light puzzle which you have to stay behind objects to avoid the light attack - try Candleman, or, Contrast by Compulsion Games. I am not complaining this game copies ideas, rather, it copies ideas and not doing well, just a collection of easy mini games without a core.  With the coarse graphics and buggy movement, nothing is impressive at all.  In my option this game failed to be a puzzle game, walking sim or action game. I may consider to rate positive if it sells for 9.99 but the listed price is 29.99, far overpriced for the limited contents and little entertainment it offers. I'd buy it again at full price. Watch the trailer, if it interests you, you'll likely love it too.

[h1] Im Reich der blutig sch√∂nen M√§rchen [/h1]   Nicht jedes Spiel vermag so grotesk widerlich wie auch wundersam sch√∂n und herzerw√§rmend zu sein. Hier steht Gewalt gegen Kinder und Tiere und Fabelwesen an der Tagesordnung und doch ist es eine wundersch√∂ne mit atmosph√§rischer einf√ºhlsamer Musik ausgeschm√ºckte M√§rchenwelt.  Ich habe jegliche Art von Toden mitgenommen, was manchmal auch gewissen Kletterpartien geschuldet war oder gar √ºbergro√üem Garten- und Essbesteck und obwohl das Blut an jeder Ecke sich wie ein Meer in Wellen zu meinen F√º√üen ergab, so gab es auch die Momente wo es einfach m√§rchenhaft sch√∂n und friedvoll war.  Grafisch ist es wirklich ein Genuss und auch der Einbezug nordischer Fabelwesen und Legenden und vielem mehr hat dieser Welt ihr Leben eingehaucht, auch wenn der Tod nie fern war.  Ja √ºber die Kameraf√ºhrung m√∂gen sich die Geister scheiden, doch ich sagte mir einst, der Kameramann muss einfach stark betrunken gewesen sein und wenn das nicht in eine nordische Welt geh√∂rt, was dann?  Aus aller Herzensg√ºte sollte man dieses kleine Indie-Spielchen einfach genie√üen und wertsch√§tzen, anstatt es wegen Kleinigkeiten in Dornen zu h√ºllen, es ist wahrlich ein Werk an dem Menschen mit Freude und Tiefe gearbeitet haben und trotz seiner kurzen Zeit, war es das alle Mal wert.   In dem Sinne, gehabt euch wohl und danke.

This is a very cool storytelling game, good amount of horror and gore, and doesn't rely on cheap scares. It was very fun to put together the story as the game progressed, through clues, the environment, and the main story line. I played through the whole thing in one sitting, it was almost as enthralling to me as that well was to Olle.

From the first hour I wanted to write a review but I had a hope for some real puzzles and more game play than running and jumping. It's sad how this nice environment and graphics are wasted with poor game play. Another thing is the story, I don't like how random it is, I felt like pieces cut pieces are put together but never completed.  But again nice graphics and environment. I would recommend it in 12$ price range.

I absolutely hate to do this. I love games like this. I like that this is an indie game and I hate having to downvote a game someone clearly put a lot of time and effort into making.   That being said, this game was the most repetitious and unengaging knockoff of little nightmares that I have ever played. The story is relatively unconnected and the level design is far more akin to a walking simulator than anything else. The checkpoints were pretty unforgiving in the sense that you are forced to redo the most boring, unengaging "puzzles" over and over again because you jumped the wrong direction or your ankle got clipped by whatever bad thing is being shot at you.   I play challenging games. But there is no reason for a game like this to be so challenging. The final boss was so redundant and frustrating I couldn't stand it. It was just time consumption for the sake of ensuring this 4 hour experience wasn't a two hour experience. There were several parts of the game that were unnaturally elongated so that it wasn't too short.   Most of the horror is shock horror with no real depth to it besides, "I murdered a baby, here's it's corpse" or "check out all this gore". It lacked any real depth. I get they were going for the Grimm fairy tale, disturbing, vapid story-telling, but it just can't keep my interest for the whole 4 hours. I forced myself to beat this game, I was done with it about an hour and a half in. $30 for this is HIGHWAY ROBBERY. I got it on sale and I still feel like I was scammed.  I really don't understand why everyone is so in love with this. It's shallow and boring.
Absoluter Wahnsinn! Mehr kann ich dazu nicht sagen.

[h1]Tutorial & controls:[/h1] The tutorial is subtle and easy on the eyes. The game uses the very known and common WASD scheme for KBM that makes everything very intuitive. The controller is equally simple but users may face incompatibility issues that require driver updates.  [h1]User interface:[/h1] The game disregards having a UI; you rarely pick up items or have to interact with your inventory. It tries to minimize the immersion breaking feeling that a bad UI can bring, so it chose to have none. Sometimes a prompt can be seen on screen, sort of a QTE, but not really; in this case, they are quite visible and on your face, as they should be.  [h1]Graphics & art style:[/h1] The graphics and art style are mesmerizing and unique. The contrast between adorable and grotesque results in a very artistic duality that may cause a reaction in the player.  [h1]Voices, music, and sound design:[/h1] Flawless sound design with sound effects impeccably chosen and implemented. The right sound at the right time often resonated as a living part of the game environment; sounds were perfectly selected, designed, and curated to give living things more life. Superb music choices that give an opportunity for exploration into the world of great Swedish classics like ‚ÄòDem Blomstertid Nu Kommer‚Äô that will remark the contrast in the game‚Äôs dichotomy even more. The sound design, in my opinion, is simply perfect.  [h1]Environment & level design:[/h1] The game‚Äôs nature has the player explore many different environments within the game‚Äôs duality. Cute and vivid in colors and life, you wish to delve in, juxtaposed to macabre and gorey scenes you wish to end asap. Navigating the game‚Äôs environment in full immersion is truly an experience. The way the atmosphere is set up is such a great statement for good game design.  [h1]Characters:[/h1] The characters we meet in our journey are mainly derived from John Bauer‚Äôs works and Sweden‚Äôs mithology. As for the game‚Äôs polarized nature, the models design swing like a pendulum between adorable and grotesque, from smiling gnomes with lovely laughter to evil trolls with cruel facial features ready to chomp on you. All 3D models are evidently carefully crafted with great attention to detail that does not break the idiosyncrasies of the overall artistic style of the game. This style is very pleasing to the eyes. It might be the mix of realistic proportions with the at times cartoonish stylization, perhaps, but there is something unique to this style that I can‚Äôt really put into words; it is simply lovely and mesmerizing.  [h1]Story & storytelling:[/h1] This is where this game truly shines. The game has the player follow a story through stories. A great narration will have us navigate several mithologic or folkloric tales of the northern lands while we struggle to achieve our goal of finishing our own journey. The stories are told through classic narration, environmental exposure, and in-game events. The narrator, Nola Klop, will lend her incredible voice and interpretation skills to accompany Olle in his, at times, lonley journey to meet Lillemore and other creatures. You will also find fable books and diaries to complement the game's exposure and narration. This being said, the game is great at what it is; the story telling is split into chapters, like any good book, and has the player follow a [b]very linear and established path, which will culminate in the same ending... every time.[/b] . The game‚Äôs pace is at first slow, then picks up and fully launches you into the experience. ¬† [h1]Target audience:[/h1] While at first glance, the game may seem adorable and cute, [b]I would not suggest this game to anyone under 15 AT LEAST[/b]. The scenes this game hides within can be extremely heavy on the heart. Newborn babies get killed, extreme gorey scenes and sudden death animations out of nowhere. I would not suggest playing this with your nephew, niece, or younger siblings. Some themes pictured in the game are potently sorrowful and woefully charged, with extremely graphic content to go along with them. ¬† [h1]Gameplay & game mechanics:[/h1] Gampelay is as simplistic as it gets in a story-driven game. Follow Olle on his adventure through lesser-known Nordic folklore and defeat several iconic figures. Do so by solving puzzles and avoiding dangers to tip-toe your way to the next area. There is no great gameplay with incredible gear combinations, nor is there some challenging mechanic for resource management or fighting technique to be learned. You are Olle, a little child in a fantastic world, and this is his story. [b]The game knows what it is[/b], what its genre is, and doesn‚Äôt try to be anything else; it is a great example of interactive story-telling where the player's hand is held through the whole journey to discover a great tale of ups and downs, of fear and laughter, of nature‚Äôs dichotomy in beauty and brutality. If you do not like games like [b]Inside[/b] or [b]Little Nightmares[/b], then this is not your game. Bramble directly feeds on this genre of interactive story-telling; if you want some action-packed game, move along; this ain't your style. ¬† [h1]Variety of foes:[/h1] From the many Scandinavian folklore and ghost stories to John Bauer references, the game puts the player against many different creatures and bosses, always following a contained narrative. One of my favorites is Pesta, the personification of the plague, and Skogsr√•, the gorgeous devil-tailed shapeshifter. Each boss belongs to a specific tale, being it‚Äôs defeat the end of said narration. Going from one boss to the next and walking through its story is a great way to learn more about Scandinavian lore. There are half a dozen bosses before the end. The bosses included in the game are [spoilers ahead]: [spoiler] The butcher, The troll, N√§cken, K√§rrh√§xan, Skogsr√•, Pesta, and finally the final boss, The mountain King.[/spoiler] ¬† [h1]Gameplay length and replayability:,[/h1] [b]Lengthwise:[/b] I feel like in 5 hours I have completed the game and seen everything it has to offer. I took my time in every little scenario and felt like I saw everything, good and bad, although I missed some figurines. The game‚Äôs length must be one of its biggest flaws, but I feel like it ends in the right spot. Artificially lengthening the game might have led to a boring outcome. [b]Replayability:[/b] There is absolutely no reason to replay the game once the veil of mystery has been removed. I‚Äôd like to have more excuses than simple achievements to dive back into the game‚Äôs gorgeous worlds. Sadly, there is no incentive to replay at all, and obviously, there is no ‚ÄòNew Game +‚Äô concept. Replaying the game forces you to go through the same slow-paced sections, with close to nothing to explore aside from the already-heard tale. ¬† [h1]The game‚Äôs biggest flaws:[/h1] When the player abandons the establish path or ryhtm, the enemies may bug out and scripted events may lose their impact. Like walls exploding by their own whill instead of zombies breaking them because they left after you stood still4. Some animations are a little flawed and stutter, but that‚Äôs just me nitpicking. Camera angles sometimes behave strangely. If you do not go the way the game wants you to go, the camera can flip out and confuse itself into a buggy scene. Limited or absolutely no power over the story. At least, several endings would‚Äôve been nice to have. Short game with no replayability at all. ¬† [h1]Conclusion:[/h1] Buy it when it's on sale. The art style and narration are flawless and enticing. If you like interactive story telling, this is your game 100%. The game contains some serious gore and grotesque content that may not be appropriate for younger or more sensitive audiences. I‚Äôd say this game deserves attention, but 30,00‚Ç¨ might be a bit much for a 5-6 hours experience. Sadly, the game suffers from the "one use only experience" syndrome, and this conditions my conclusion for the game‚Äôs worth in money.

Die nordische Mythologie kann verspielt und anmutig sein. Aber auch grausam und brutal. Zwischen diesen beiden Extremen schwankt [b]Bramble: The Mountain King[/b]. Der Spieler begeleiter den 8-j√§hrigen Olle, der eines Nachts feststellt, dass seine kaum √§ltere Schwester ausgeb√ºchst ist. Was als ein harmloser Spaziergang im n√§chstlichen Wald beginnt endet in den tiefen heidnischer Sagen. Den schonbald muss Olle feststellen, dass seine Schwester von einem brutalen Troll entf√ºhrt wurde, damit aus ihr ein leckeres H√§ppchen f√ºr einen gefangenen K√∂nig wird.   Was zun√§chst nach einer 08/15-Fantasystory klingt entpuppt sich als verst√∂rende Reise, die neben niedlichen Gnomen auch allerlei grausiges zu bieten hat. W√§hrend viele klassische Horrorspiele auf Schockmomente setzen, verzichten Bramble darauf fast vollkommen. Es sind vielmehr die Bilder und Geschichten, die einen echten, wahnhafften Horror beim Spieler bewirken. So muss sich alle mal durch die blutigen Fleischreste eines Trollkochs k√§mpfen, durch ein von der Pest verzehrtes Dorf oder durch die Seelen ermorderter Kinder. Das Spiel spart dabei nicht mit den grausigen Details. Wir bekommen alles zu sehen. Alles. Bemerkenswert bleibt, dass Bramdle trotz dieser grausamen Thematik zu keinem Zeitpunkt voyeuristisch wird. In jedem Moment in dem Olle durch die brutale Welt stolpert, f√ºhlen wir seine Verzweiflung, seinen Schmerz, seine Wut, seine Angst. Zu keinem Zeitpunkt wollen wir verweilen. Davon ausgenommen sind nur einige kurze Phasen, in denen die dunkle Stimmung durch einen Moment der Hoffnung unterbrochen wird und in dem wir uns f√ºr einen kurzen Moment sicherf√ºhlen.  Brandle lebt nicht von seiner Story. Es lebt von den Bildern und der Athmosph√§re. Ohne eine beeindruckende Grafik zu zeigen, gelingt es Brandle eine Spielwelt aufzubauen, in der wir versinken, ohne es zu wollen. Untermalt wird das Ganze durch einen grandiosen Soundtrack, der zu jedem Zeitpunkt perfekt passt.   Spielereich ist Brandle die meiste Zeit Walking Simulator. Wir schauen vor allem zu. Unterbrochen wird dies vor allem dann, wenn ein Jump'n'Run-Passage kommt oder ein Bosskampf ansteht. W√§hrend ersteres spielereich kaum fordernd ist, sind die Bossk√§mpfe gelungen und im Stil der alten Schule gehalten. Wir m√ºssen die Mechaniken durch Try and Error herausfinden und schlie√ülich meistern. Das gef√§llt mir gut, gerade auch in einem so kurzen Spiel. Dabei ist unser Alter Ego mit Nichten unsterblich. Er wird gefressen, erschlagen, zerschnitten und zerquetscht werden. Da ist sowohl sch√∂n, dass die automatischen Speicherpunkte sehr fair verteilt sind, wie auch schade, dass es genauso ist. Mich hat das bereits fr√ºhzeitig animiert, Olle absichtlich in den Tod zu schicken. Einfach, weil ich wissen wollte, was passiert. Schlimm war es nie, der letzte Speicherpunkt war h√∂chstens eine Minute zur√ºck. Schade, so ist die vom Spiel produzierte Gefahr √ºberschaubar. Da das Gef√ºhl etwas geleister zu haben sich nach 10 bis 20 erfolglosen Bossk√§mpfen trotzdem einstellt, mag ich das aber verzeihen.  Im Ergebnis gibt es bei mir eine klare Empfehlung f√ºr all diejnigen, die ein kurzes Intermezzo mit Horrorelementen w√ºnschen.

It was wonderful seeing familiar Nordic creatures and setting in a video game. While there are intense moments and terrifying enemies, the game is only nominally horror-flavored. It could perhaps be compared to a Brothers Grimm story where a seemingly innocent story is laden with disturbing details, not so much heart-pounding anxiety.   The environments are absolutely beautiful and the gameplay straightforward enough that the game is easy for casual players to pick up. However, there are some difficulty spikes which may get in the way of the enjoyment of those players who went in expecting a leisurely stroll through an interactive storybook. One of my frustrations with the demo was that it wasn't always clear what you were supposed to do and the same applies to the full game.   Aside from a few frustrating bits I enjoyed Bramble a lot. Perfect if you're looking for a game you can finish in a weekend, with many memorable encounters and an immersive atmosphere.

tldr; It's a litte nightmare clone that is a downgrade from the original. It doesn't push the genre forward.  If you really like little nightmares then you will find this entertaining enough. It's likely I will finish it at some point but feel I'm better off just replaying little nightmares. I wish they tried to be different here.. but I see nothing but a clone.  1. The story feels forced. 2. The world is pretty but underneath it feels empty. 3. It tries to be real to fairy tales but it seems just stitched up together randomly. None of the scenes/stories/whatever seem to tell a larger one.  Still again.. if you are desperate for little nightmares there is a game here you may enjoy.  If you never played LN don't play this first!
If you like Little Nightmares, Inside or Limbo, this can be your game.  Beware it's short.   I got it on sale, worth it.
Une belle surprise vraiment! Je recommande vivement.

[h1]Wundervolles, magisch-brutales M√§rchen[/h1]  Dass der Junge h√∂chst sportliche Leistungen in Hausschlappen vollbringt, ist erstaunlich, sei aber nicht Mittelpunkt dieser Rezension. Das traditionelle Outfit des Kleinen ist eines von vielen Details, die eine wunderbare Atmosph√§re alter M√§rchenb√ºcher erzeugen. Die nordische Sagenwelt wird gelungen aufgegriffen und viele Figuren, die aus √§hnlich platzierten Titeln wie z.B. [i]Unforgiving[/i] bekannt sind, tauchen in einer neuen, ergreifenden Inszenierung auf. Bewegt man sich zun√§chst in einer √ºberwiegend zauberhaft anmutenden Welt, steigert sich die Dramatik und die Brutalit√§t mit zunehmendem Spiel- und Handlungsverlauf. Das ist auch unglaublich wichtig, da es Spannung aufbaut und immer weiter ans Geschehen fesselt. Die Entwicklung des Protagonisten aufgreifend, ver√§ndert sich der zun√§chst etwas kindlich-naiv anmutende Grundton der Welt immer weiter zu einem bitterernsten und grausamen Drama, ganz im Tonfall alter M√§rchen und Sagen. Themen wie ritueller Kindesmissbrauch, Mord und Suizid begr√ºnden die USK18-Freigabe und die Triggerwarnung bei Spielstart absolut, verleihen dem Titel aber auch eine gewisse W√ºrze.  Ganz klar ist, dass dieses Spiel von einer gro√üartigen Grafik und Musik lebt. Bemerkenswert ist zudem, dass diese im Verlauf des Spiels tats√§chlich immer besser, komplexer und interessanter wird. Vollkommen begeistert hat mich das Finale, das sich auch musikalisch zunehmend steigert. [spoiler]W√§hrend der Soundtrack zun√§chst sehr individuell klingt, entwickelt er sich mit jeder Boss-Battle-Stufe weiter, bis hin zu einer Interpretation des ber√ºhmten Themas aus Peer Gynt. Ja, der titelgebende [i]Mountain King[/i] ist tats√§chlich [b]der[/b] Bergk√∂nig aus dem Werk von Edvard Grieg, was mir zun√§chst garnicht bewusst war. [/spoiler] Ich finde es toll, wie diese klassische Gestalt so gelungen in einen modernen Videospielboss √ºbertragen wurde.  Ein bisschen was zu n√∂rgeln gibt es nat√ºrlich auch. Das Spiel ist √§u√üerst linear, was mich aus Sicht der Handlungsf√ºhrung garnicht mal st√∂rt, durchaus aber mit Blick auf die Levelgestaltung und Herausfordungen. Zwar wechseln sich die m√§√üig innovativen Puzzle h√§ufig ab, so dass es interessant bleibt, doch h√§tte hier ein wenig mehr Handlungsfreiheit nicht geschadet.   Ein absolutes No-Go ist, dass alle Buttons in einem Kreissymbol statt ihrer physischen Tastenform angezeigt werden. Das finde ich  √§u√üerst verwirrend, weil der Kreis visuell den Controller-Stick suggeriert und ich jedes mal erst nachdenken musste, welche der Buchstabenfolgen LS, LT oder LB gleich wieder welchen Controller-Button meint. Durch bessere grafische Darstellung w√§re das - f√ºr mich - viel intuitiver.   Vor allem anfangs st√∂rt mich auch eine gewisse subtile Dissonanz und fehlendes Feingef√ºhl in der Inszenierung. So wird der Wald von der Erz√§hlerin als gruselig und angsteinfl√∂√üend beschrieben, doch erscheint er grafisch eher magisch und einladend, keineswegs gef√§hrlich. Das passt ebenso wenig zusammen, wie manche Tastenzuordnungen. Dass z.B. das Ducken (d.h. Figur bewegt sich [i]runter[/i]) einen Griff nach [i]oben[/i] (Bumperbutton) statt nach [i]unten[/i] (Triggerbutton) erfordert, f√ºhlt sich f√ºr mich widerspr√ºchlich an.   Einige Endbosse sind zun√§chst etwas knifflig, weil die Programmierung mit Ausl√∂sesituation arbeitet, d.h. wenn "Skogsr√•", eine gro√üartig inszenierte Femme Fatal des Waldes, zum Angriff schie√üt, so trifft sie scheinbar immer, wenn bei Abwurf die Spielfigur in der Sichtlinie stand. Ein Ausweichen in letzter Minute, das die Interaktion erheblich interessanter machen w√ºrde, ist damit unm√∂glich.  Aller kleinen M√§ngel zum Trotz, ist dies ein fantastisches Spiel, bei dem sich das Durchspielen lohnt, da es immer besser wird. Die Story ist kurzweilig, gut konstruiert und inszeniert und die nordische Sagenwelt wird sehr gelungen neu, aber dennoch traditionell interpretiert. Die Steuerung ist letztlich nicht all zu kompliziert und die Bossfights sind mit etwas √úbung gut machbar. Auf jeden Fall eine Spielempfehlung!

Uno de los mejores juegos que he jugado. Buenos gr√°ficos, buena historia y buena ambientaci√≥n. Muy econ√≥mico para lo que es el juego en s√≠ (hay juegos de menor calidad a mucho m√°s alto el precio). Si lo compr√°s en oferta un golazo. Recomendado.

This game's a dark one for sure, and real creepy many times. The infused horror elements are really good and I've found myself ill at ease several times. It's got an atmosphere of great melancholy and despair, they've captured this perfectly in all its grimness. While playing this game, as a Swede myself, I often feel and recognize the immense depth and darkness of the Swedish/Northen folk lore and old world fairy tales with all their dark and brutal things that moves and lurks in the Northen mysterious fairy tale nights. It makes me reconnect with my childhood stories with the fascination and dread I felt back then when I heard and read them. I couldn't get enough of them when I was a kid. But, the game's also honey sweet at times with a myriad little curious creatures and personas of the small people of the fay which makes up a fine balance between the darkness and the light, It's a rich game filled to the brim with curious little things, beauty and sweet innocence that is in stark contrast to the heavy darkness that permeates the world. It's a rather unusual a game and I love it. The guys behind it has made a fantastic job of it.

If you played and loved Myst and want to see the whole Island free to roam almost any where then this is for you. I'd also say that if you never played Myst before, your missing out on a great, and a game changer that affected  multiple games even to this day. You really should check it out. Myst has aged beautifully over the years and this update makes it as pretty as it will ever be. The only thing I really wish they had added was a voice over reading the main books. buy on sale all day long!!!

Myst isn't for everyone, but you might find yourself getting lost and filled with curiosity the way I first did when I played it on CD-ROM, and then re-enjoyed it in full 3D with RealMyst ME.

I played this way back when it first came out, as well as the whole series - Myst is the game that made and broke the mold.  It hasn't lost its beauty or luster compared to the plethora of games that have come out since it splashed onto the game scene in the '90's, and it still stands strong and alone compared to games that are out today.  In my opinion, the intriguing, challenging puzzles still own the standard for both logic and using your brain matter to think outside the box, without the hand holding of many games nowadays.  There may not be hand holding, but there are definitely enough clues within the game to make any frustration worth it, because you WILL figure it out if you pay attention, make connections, follow logic and think.  It's all there - you just have to keep your eyes open and your thinking cap on. It had been so long since I'd first played Myst, I found that though many puzzles were familiar, they had to be "re-thunk" and figured out all over again.  I've loved it and am looking forward to completing realMyst and continuing on to replay the rest of the series.

A faithful and lovingly detailed remake of an all-time classic adventure game.

Myst is a puzzle game, not a shoot'em up...

This one one of the first games I played as a kid on a desktop. Back then, I struggled heavily to understand "what is this?". I mostly was interested in Myst because I had grown up in Spokane and people there were proud of the game developers.  I'll admit, I cheated when I was a kid. Back then though, finding a game walk-through was nearly impossible and definitely unreliable. When I finished, I had no idea what I had done or the meaning of a puzzle adventure.   Now, as an adult, I finished the game on my own! (Yay for me!). For anyone else, know that this game is a great puzzler with some great story that you have to pay attention in order to glean value. You might even need to take notes! Really, it's worth a buy as is, but waiting for a sale is nice too. Hope you enjoy!

It was great what they tried to do with this. Bringing a more fully 3d experience to the original Myst, while still holding true to the sights and sounds of the original. I think they did it well. It really is amazing to first play the original Myst (nostalgia!!!), and then play this version after. Just being able to 'look up' or turn at certain areas, breathed life into what would have originally been a very confusing and rigid view.  The addition of some canon material about Veovis, D'ni, and then Rime, was really a nice touch as a hint for things to come or what you discover from the books.  Overall... still a beautiful adventure to enjoy.
Very good game.  Don't cheat yourself and look things up!
Beat the game in less than 2 minutes 10/10

[b]TLDR[/b] If you‚Äôve never played the original, this is the one to try: although a bit outdated, it‚Äôs still an enjoyable introduction to the world of Myst and the puzzles hold pretty well. [17/20‚≠ê, 8hüèÖ, 3/5üí°]  [b]Context[/b] This one is tough to review. I had previously played the original Myst and [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/macwh/recommended/63660/?snr=1_1056_1055_1056]Myst: ME[/url], but not any realMYST incarnation. So how should look at the value of realMYST: ME? As standalone game in 2021? A standalone in 2014 when it was released? realMYST: ME in comparison with non-ME realMYST? (Actually, never played non-ME realMYST and it‚Äôs not available, so this one doesn‚Äôt count) realMYST in comparison to regular Myst or Myst: ME? Or just the Myst family of games as an abstract concept?  Let me start with Myst in general for newcomers. At its core, Myst is essentially a sequence of mostly unconnected puzzles. What made it some innovative was that the authors were able to crafty build a credible world and lore around this, which still holds pretty well by today‚Äôs standards. In terms of difficulty, people often complain they feel lost due to the non-linearity and the lack of hints for solving the puzzles. In my humble opinion, non-linearity is a positive trait of this kind of adventure puzzle games. As for hints, I didn‚Äôt find any puzzle for which there weren‚Äôt clues and had to be brute forced. Granted, some of these are rather difficult to catch, and you need to be alert for every clue in the environment (including sound cues, got stuck a couple of times for disregarding this). The game is also rather short by today‚Äôs standards.  [b]Writing[/b] The plot is the same as the original [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/macwh/recommended/63660/?snr=1_1056_1055_1056]Myst: ME[/url]. The player controls an unnamed character (The Stranger) that has fallen into a deserted age (the titular Myst). The player has to explore different ages to understand what happened to Myst and eventually escape.  [b]Aesthetics[/b] Focusing on realMYST as a standalone, for those who‚Äôve never played the original Myst (or other similar pre-rendered games), the real-time 3D navigation provides a more modern experience without sacrificing much in terms of puzzle-solving. The controls feel natural, although I did encounter a few bugs (interactions that stopped working, elevators that stopped moving, stuck in rooms after controls stopped responding). In terms of graphics, I‚Äôd say they look a bit dated even for 2014. One that I think is subpar is the soundtrack (but that was already an issue with the original version).  [b]Gameplay[/b] For those coming from the original Myst, I felt the new 3D movement makes for a less frustrating experience when exploring the world, so I understand the need for this remake. (I went and re-played Myst:ME after realMYST:ME, and even though I knew what I had to do, sometimes I still couldn‚Äôt find the right place to click). I‚Äôve tried the option to use classic point-and-click navigation in the 3D world and it didn‚Äôt really feel natural, even considering I was used to pre-rendered games. However, the realMYST 3D graphics feel more hollow, and the game loses some of ‚Äúmystique‚Äù that was caused by the beautiful, sometimes eerie, pre-renders of the original Myst.   You can't die nor hit deadends, you can save at any point, and it also auto-saves.  [b]Value[/b] The game took me about 8h to complete. You cannot revisit previous chapters, but there are multiple save slots. Achievements are related to the progress and finding some hidden interactions, and don't require additional playthroughs. There are multiple endings, but determined by a last-minute decision.   PS: I‚Äôm pretty sure these are the only games I‚Äôve played without support for subtitles. Considering that the spoken parts are from 90s live action footage with added interference, I can‚Äôt really understand this decision.  [quote][i]For more puzzle-game reviews and curated lists check out the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43326007-The-Clueless-Adventurer-Puzzle-Trove/]Puzzle Trove[/url].[/i][/quote]

I've lost count of how many times I bought this game. I bought it when it was launched as it was the best experience for a new brand of PCs, called multimedia PCs (that were PCs with CD ROMs and sound cards). Then I bought it again in a bundle to get Myst III (Myst, Riven and Myst III). Bought again when it was ported to "modern" PCs (back in 2000's), again for smartphone, again here on Steam, again the masterpiece edition, again the Real Myst version and, of course, this version: Real Myst Masterpiece (I still didn't buy the VR edition, but as soon as I get a headset...). Yes, the game is that good!  You don't have to experience the original versions. They are for people like me who lived those times. This is the version you should try to get to know the game that started the puzzle adventure genre. And sincerely, Myst series is till the best.

For everyone interested in a quality if this specific edition - it's great and runs well on modern systems.  For those who have played Myst before, I don't know why you are reading this, you already know everything.  For those who like me haven't played Myst or realMyst before, I have couple things to say. I opted for this version instead of the latest remaster, and maybe I should have done the opposite. This game is a grand dad of modern immersive puzzlers and I can see it have done phenomenal job back when it was released. My issue though is that I haven't played it back then. At first I played Riven and Myst IV: Revelations, and got my hands on the first one only now.  I had the same issue with Silent Hill actually, because I started with Silent Hill 2. Compared to the sequel, original Silent Hill is really rough around the edges. And original Silent Hill games are also dated in terms of systems compared to modern survival horror games like The Evil Within 2 or Darkwood.   And it's the same when you compare Myst to Riven, and Myst to the modern immersive puzzlers. It's dated, and you gotta accept it.  But at the same time, there are clear reasons why people play Myst and Silent Hill even today. It's actually funny how two so completely different games are also so similar when trying to describe them. Even with how much more streamlined modern game design has become, both of those games did a revolutionary worldbuilding that still stands.  So, I have mixed feelings after playing Myst, since I can't say that I clearly enjoyed it because of it's rough edges. But also I can't say I didn't. Completed it in two nights, no regrets.  It's time to revisit Riven now.

As an updated remake of the original Myst, realMyst is definitely more welcoming experience, with alternate and smoother movement, achievements, a hint system, and even a new bonus age included. As a result, realMyst, alongside the 2021 version of Myst, are probably the best ways for newcomers to enjoy Myst in this day and age, unless you really wish to experience a classic, warts and all.  The most noticeable change realMyst offers is its actual 3D environment to move around in, with inclusion of both a classic-like point-and-click movement system and WASD movement, both of which feel good to use after adjusting to their quirks. As a result, it‚Äôs much easier to navigate the world and have more control in where one is going, so getting lost and not going where you want to go is less of an issue. The environment itself also transitioned well from pre-rendered pictures to 3D, with the animations and environment looking incredibly nice, with a few additional secrets to find.   Overall, realMyst is a great way for newcomers to experience Myst without having to deal with the most noticeable limitations and datedness of the original, with thinks such as in-game hints, achievements, and the new bonus age being additional fantastic quality-of-life additions. It, alongside potentially the 2021 remake, are by now the definitive ways of playing and enjoying Myst for newcomers.

Un referente en la industria. Actualmente sigue siendo un excelente t√≠tulo.  10/10 Soy gran admirador de la obra de los hermanos Miller, Incluso tengo los tres libros que publicaron en espa√±ol.

I absolutely love Myst for all it's obtuseness and delightful puzzling, but as of 2021 unless you're using a toaster of a computer or you have nostalgia for realMYST in particular, you have absolutely zero reason to play this version of the game over the new remake. This version controls really weirdly and lacks important QoL changes implemented in the remake (which range from making things you can interact with more obvious to being able to carry more than one red/blue page at a time.)  If there's any reason to bother with it, it's probably just for the Rime Age. But even then, that's a very short segment that exists mostly to connect the original game up with Riven better. So yeah, unless you're dead set on knowing absolutely every fragment of Myst lore, are doing a full retrospective or have weird nostalgia for this odd iteration of the game, you're better off just going with classic Masterpiece Edition or the 2021 remake.

Still great. Puzzles are "logical", as in there are symbols in one place and you recognise these symbols on some other machine. But there is nothing to connect place and machine otherwise. 90s puzzles. You need to play with sound. It's otherwise not completable. The graphics really need a gamma setting, everything is super dark. Also you run around with a flashlight, basically like Doom. So much face palm.

I loved the atmosphere and ambiance of Myst, something that many games today lack. I often found myself picking up the books and reading about the adventures and lore of a particular world before jumping in and solving their puzzles. This helped create an illusion of depth. I felt that many of the puzzles were not well balanced. They varied drastically in difficulty, which resulted in frustration. The game looked good considering its age, but the liver spots quickly become apparent as the game progressed.  If you look at Myst in a vacuum and try to compare it to other puzzle games of today it simply falls short in many aspects. But this shouldn't be at all surprising, considering Myst was made in 1993. Myst is the kind of game that you need to appreciate from the right perspective. None will argue that the great puzzle games of today stand upon the shoulders of giants, and Myst was an achievement of its time.

It took me a bit to get moving in this game. I had lots of leads, but nothing was progressing. Once the first piece actually moved, my progress came quickly, until the very end, where I had a bit of trouble and an issue with one of the mechanics. There were some small bugs, such as going up platforms that rotate around a wall, but nothing game breaking.  The story is not delivered neatly in this game, and it's possible to miss much of it. By paying attention, reading, and listening, I was able to get the gist of the story, and actually found it quite interesting. I ended up greatly enjoying this game. I remember it from when I was a kid, but never played it. I'm glad I finally did. I wishlisted the rest of the games and will scoop them up when there is a sale, as I'm interested to know where the story goes. Price is a bit high for the amount of content, but worth it on sale.
great game to play------hard but fun to hunt for the way out!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I played Myst as a kid on our old Gateway 2000 in Windows 95. It was a great game then, just limited by the capabilities of the time. Things looked great, but always felt like you were just moving around viewing images.  realMyst brings that all more modern, while still maintaining the classic Myst feel. I played, with the classic Myst style, only switching at times required to get some of the achievements. This is a game great for all ages. It really tests your knowledge and ability to pick up clues and piece them together.
Classic Myst redone with this century's technology.

[b]"Myst" was a point and click game that set some new standards for puzzle games back on early 90s' and pushed the genre forward. Surreal locations, weird atmosphere, clever puzzles and controls mechanics were some of its characteristics. "RealMyst" is a well made remake that offers better graphics and sound quality into a fully 3d environment. Some navigational problems and minor control issues cannot ruin the overall great experience. Classic.   Manometer: 8/10[/b]   The good - Nice graphics for early 00s' with great atmospheric lighting. A good upgrade compared to the original game. - Beautifully designed world. Unique buildings and some surreal locations with strong identity. A quick look at a snapshot and you know that this is "Myst". - Clever and well built puzzles. They are not too difficult but challenging enough. The original game was revolutionary at this kind of mechanical puzzles and inspired a lot of game after it. - Nice sound design on the environment. Puzzles' sounds are very helpful too. - Although it has not exactly a plot, the backstory that you read at the books is enough to succeed a dark, mysterious, weird atmosphere for the entire game. - Well written, interesting texts. You can read them all without getting bored. - Cool acting performances, although they are a bit extravagant. - Day/night system that you usually find in some other genres (e.g. open world) is a nice addition that offers more realism and enhances the atmosphere. - It has multiple endings. - It is clever that it throws you at the start of the game without explaining you anything about its logic and backstory. You have to discover it by yourself like a real explorer.  The bad - There are some navigational issues. At classic mode camera's movement isn't very smooth with constant unreasonable zoom ins - outs. It can easily cause motion sickness. At free modes there are some glitches in movement especially after interacting with an object. - The mouse cursor often does not change shape when hovering over some interactive objects and this can be confusing. Control mechanics at 1-2 puzzles are a bit clunky. - Although it has multiple endings none of them ends the game properly. There are no credits or something that tells you it's over. It just lets you staring and wondering if this is it. Not rewarding at all.

[b] Has not aged well. [/b]  MYST will always be respected as the groundbreaking adventure that it was in it's day, as it should be. It brought us an experience unlike any other, and has rightfully earned it's place among the great classics.  Unfortunately however, it just hasn't aged well. To new players considering the game, try bashing your head against a wall a few times. It's cheaper and will give you much of the same feeling you'll get from playing this game and wondering what the point of that second lever was ever supposed to be. Some of the puzzles are just weak and tedious. Back in the day this game was first released, getting stuck in a game was considered content, but we played on anyway because it was all we had and didn't yet have anything better.  I'd say there are only two reasons to actually consider getting realMyst: [list] [*] For nostalgia's sake of people who played it before and want to experience it again. [*] Those like me, who played it back in the day but never got to finish it. At least I've done that now and can cross it off the list of things I wonder about at 4 AM when I'm trying to sleep. [/list] If either of those apply to you and you think it's worth the price tag, then go for it. Just make sure you have a bottle of Excedrin handy, you're going to need it.

IMHO, one of the upmost best games from the 1990's returns with total splendor! Graphics are simply gorgeous in 2k and with the added sound effects carefully placed in specific places, the immersion is absolute. Myst Masterpiece is truly that, as it brings back nostalgic memories from the original. The worlds to explore and interact with, figuring out complex puzzles-a magical,mystical place to behold. One of the best intricate games ever made. A true classic! Thanks to the devs on this masterpiece.

I have now played 3 versions of MYST, and I think realMYST is by far the best! It is such a nostalgia kick to me in my teens playing the first one when it was new, to me now in my 40's playing this much updated version. I love the realistic day/night transitions and the various birds and insects. The colors really pop out and during the daylight you can see places that used to be dark.  Playing this again for nostalgia sake is fun. Playing it to learn about the lore is fun. Actual gameplay is stale, this game has not aged well. There is no jeopardy or risk. You can skip the 4 ages, get the page from the marker switch and just go and save Atrus. Game over. In Riven & Exile you can die, there are consequences that tug at your heart.  The 5th age Rime, while frightening with scary whale monsters in the background, offers itself only as an advertisement for Riven. Btw that crystal lock is way to hard to figure out, changing the crystal colors is too hard! MYST is beautiful and filled with lore. After playing Riven you know why Catherine never saw the note on the grass. Also it is implied that Savedro from Exile burned the books in the library. I love the tie-ins! But would I recommend this to new players of the series? No.  It is not necessary to begin here, come back to it later. Riven, Exile & Uru are much more compelling!
Absolutely loved playing the original as a kid, realMyst is the closest I can get to that experience without actually getting an old installation going, and its glorious.
Real Myst is more aesthetically pleasing than the original, and the addition of "Rime" was appreciated.

Qui ne conna√Æt pas GTA ? Cette s√©rie embl√©matique du jeu-vid√©o...  C'est simple en fait, c'est un jeu (assez) r√©cent, bien fait, qui propose pas mal de possibilit√©s et de soir√©es de fun entre amis. Rockstar est √©videmment encore extr√™mement actif sur le jeu, ce qui fait qu'on se retrouve tr√®s souvent √† avoir des missions / braquages / activit√©s qui sortent, donc le jeu ne meurt globalement jamais.  Malheureusement, l'argent est primordial en multijoueur, sans argent on ne fait en fait juste rien. On a pas d'armes, pas de v√©hicules, enfin globalement rien.  Pour ce qui est du solo l'histoire est sympa, en plus de proposer un style de jeu original avec 3 personnages jouables et switchables durant certaines missions, ou tout le temps en "mode libre".  Si vous n'avez pas ce jeu et que vous souhaitez un jeu qui vous permet de faire les cons avec vos amis, effectuer des missions et devenir un √©norme criminel dans une ville qui vous le permet, c'est le jeu qu'il vous faut.

I'll simply enumerate pros and cons in my opinion;  pros: -the narrator is simply excellent, the monologue(or dialogue) is well-thought and perfect -the turn-based combat is very good and easy to learn -the tutorials are very clear and simple -strategy is really the key to victory -loyalty rewards (such as battleblock theater skins) -classic behemoth humor is still there as always and very appreciated  cons: -the UI seems not adapted for PC -character stats are a bit hard to understand at first -does not autosave often enough -some elements seems pixelated (low quality graphics) even if running ultra settings (I know it's still early access)  conclusion: Buy it, it is worth your money awesome game made by awesome people. looking forward to future updates and additional content.

Pit People is XCOM, Fire Emblem, and Pokemon thrown into the minds of Behemoth and what they made is a funny and good looking game. The meat of the game is doing battle with teams of bad guys with your very own squad that you find through the story mode until you find Sophia the Recruitador (a lot of characters in this game have funny names). Then, the game branches into another way of playing it. You can capture any unit you fight on the battlefield when you leave it as the last one alive. There are several character classes from the human fighters to the penguins to the beefy giants to the cupcake healer class. Every character has their own name from Gluten to Pipistrella.  This is an early access title as of January, and it shows only in the story mode. The rest of the game is polished and balanced with each weapon type and class, but the story mode is farly short. What it lacks in length it makes up in character and gameplay. The narrator Stamper was present in their previous game Battleblock Theater as well but he takes the role of a godlike bear that overlooks the story as a sort of meta-narrator, talking to the characters and talking to the player. Apart from the short story quests, there are a few side quests that are all five parts incrasing in difficulty. These serve the same purpose as side quests in different games, to give you some more gold and flesh out the characters. These side quests take a bit longer than the story.   Apart from the insanely fun singleplayer, there exists an in-universe multiplayer PvP called the Pit, which is pretty much the only reference to the title of the game. You and a partner control your squads to defeat two other people's squads. It's a very satisfying game mode as you can learn from the other people's squad composition to increase chances of success. Think XCOM PvP. You get story rewards as well depending on how many games you win per day. As it is now, Pit People is very fun and well balanced even though the story mode was short and as sweet as the cupcake healer class.

Knight, move to A55 Person reading this, move to "Add to Cart" What are you waiting for  Ok now for the serious review. I've recently completed story mode for Pit People (Yet to complete all Achievements, I WILL do it!), and the game has everything I personally wanted from the game. good Story development, a villian you can hate for a reason, and really funny jokes. With Early Acess, It has all the content for a small story, If it was only this for the final release, I'd personally enjoy it. Honestly I'm going to rack up my Characters to level 99 and completely MELT the Pit! Oh you're thinking of the 1000 Degree knife? The story adds on to the "Behemoth" Timeline. If you're wondering what game this is going off of, it's going off of Battleblock Theater. If you don't believe me, buy the game and beat it. Mechanics in the game are well-executed (personally, in my opinion). It introduces a Hexagonal Turn-base mechanic where you have to use Geometry to make any sense out of this.. (Note, you don't have to have that much knowledge). Will Stamper, there's Will Stamper. They got the legendary comedian Will Stamper. Just like Battleblock Theater, I might have a reason to beat the game. Unlike any Early Acess Games, I couldn't find any bugs when just casually playing it. It's well constructed, and like I said earlier, It feels like this is the full game. If you, the reader, are reading this, I highly recommend you buy this.  If you can spare $15, just buy this, buy this for your family, and buy it for your dog.

If you liked any of their games before, you'll absolutely love this one too. Their cheeky take on a turn-based strategy game was executed perfectly.  And to think this is still early acces, I can't wait for all the witty content still in the making!

The game very good and fun and funny

Like all Behemoth's games, Pit People is very polished and it brings something interesting (and funny) to the table. If you have played Castle Crashers or BattleBlock Theater, there are a lot of familiar things you will encounter - art style, humor and the narrator to mention a few.  Pit People does not necessarily innovate something new. Rather, it combines mechanics from many popular games and ends up creating quite an interesting result. You will feel the presence of XCOM, Fire Emblem, Skulls of the Shogun or damn, even Pokemon. Most of the time games mixing that many ideas would end up being bad. This is not the case with Pit People - it feels truly original.  The combat is plain simple but vast collection of different unit types and items make this game quite strategical. There are endless amount of combos to test and new interesting characters to find.  Lastly, I wouldn't be too worried about the Early Access tag on this game. Sure, most of the main story is missing (you can only complete about 5% of it) but there is still a lot to do in this version. There are multiple plot driven side quests to do, units to catch and other players to crush (in online mode).   Highly recommend.

For a game that's early access, it really doesn't feel like it. I'm going to highlight what I feel is wrong/needs to be improved, in hopes the devs see it and consider it. For a review, I'll keep  it short. A very interesting world, full of LOTS of stuff, like LOTS, complete with music, great sound, and mostly good controls The music is amazing, I'll have it stuck in my head for days. Behemoth has yet another wonderful game out on the market. On to some gripes about the game.  The PC controls are mostly good, but could use some fine tuning to make them not so wonky when selecting loadouts, the default controls are questionable, but rebindable so that's not that big of a deal. Also, in the intro, the load out screen and differences between "tiers" of items (i.e. cosmetics, light helmets, heavy helmets) isn't at all explained. It was super super confusing because I had no clue what I was doing. So the tutorial could use some more fine tuning as well.   There are other things not very well explained, like what's on the HUD, I didn't know what I was looking at, or what it meant for a while. The items, such as campfires, and how to buy them isn't at all explained. I think my #1 glaring problem was the lack of explanation, so if you're reading this, Behemoth, it would be good to look into that.  These are the most notable issues I saw, but damn this game is freaking fun. Doing Coop is sooooo much fun, but online is a mess. The biggest thing this game could benefit from is more flushed out tutorials, really explaining what everythng is. Keep it up Behemoth, it's a damn good game. Also, put people queued together on the same team. Or at least have an option to.

I'm excited to see the limited amount of content grow.  Behemoth has always done a great job putting together unique games with their own sense of humor and style. As of early access, they still deliever with their signature style.  The art of Dan Paladin is ever present. Simple, humorous, delightful. There were a few times the art was pixelated but I'm sure that'll be fixed. Some of it (art, map, UI) feels a bit overly busy.  As far as content, UI, and fighting system, alot needs to be worked on. The fighting system is simple but shallow and there's two story missions along with a few side quests. I imagine over the next year (in which Behemoth works towards release) mechanics and story will be built upon.  So if you're buying it now, know you're only going to get a few hours of enjoyment at first. But if you believe the track record of the Behemoth team and their wonderfully unique spirit, it's worth to get the game now and support the team!

I usually don't get along with turn-based games but Whoa Nelly! this one just makes me love it!  Just won the Golden rewards in the Pit and i pimpd my little army, this game has everything you need! except a complete game...but you still have lots of side-quests!  Yay!?!?!?!
God it addictives!!! hope there a ton more contents coming... i mean it already great but i want more, MORE

One of the best opening scenes for any game ever. The sound quality in this game is some of the best I have ever heard. Every sound effect sound crisp and real. The music is fantastic and varied. Definitely one of the funnier games i've played also.  As far as negatives go; the controls are a bit unintuitive and are fairly clunky. Information on stats is non existant. Finding the town can be a bit of a headache because the indicator often disapears for no aparent reason.

I wasn't sure what to expect, I'm a huge fan of Castle Crashers & Battleblock Theater, but I'm not a fan of turn based games. This however, is a different story, I love this game, even in early access, it feels EXTRMELEY polished and is a joy to play, both solo and with a friend.  There's tons of hilarious items to use, tons of Behemoth humor that I love, and tons of detail to the maps/arenas. As for the gameplay, it feels arcade-y, without losing a smidge of any strategic elements, which is very hard to do. Then there's the 'hub' where they have an Arena, Online, Item Shop, Character/Group Customization, which of course, is dislayed in a humerous style (I wont spoil). The map roaming is perfect for this game, lots of content, lots of things to fight, plenty of quests and side quests to do, none of which are filler.   Props to The Behemoth for creating another awesome, masterfully crafted game that I need to recommend!

Played a bit, is good. But seriously, considering I have spent so many months on this game and have been playing since 2.0 I would say it‚Äôs a good game. TLDR: would recommend.  I feel that there quite lot to this game and it has had some great features over the years. With the multitude of official maps and community maps you shouldn‚Äôt run out of new experiences and environments. Single player is fun but most of your fun comes from multiplayer, mostly because of the verity you can find in servers. you meet a lot of interesting people in PvP and PvE and I personally have quite a few memories with my friends on all the different servers we have played on. If the surviving isn‚Äôt your thing then there is also the map editor which can be fun to mess around with, I find my self coming back to it every once and a while to mess about. Of course, there is thing that need to be fixed, the progression and risk can be improved and there could be a bigger emphasis on survival aspects like fishing and planting. I have also noticed that joining servers has become an issue.  I‚Äôm exited to see how Nelson takes this game into 4.0 and hope that it fixes most off the issues that the game currently has. It look promising. PUBG copied Unturneds arena.
To be honest its a great game would recommend it to everyone who likes zombie games.

While I enjoyed the nostalgia of playing a game that I played in the arcades back in the day, I was very disappointed that the health/time displays look god awful, and are not the original graphics at all.  Terrible font just sitting there, reminding you this is an emulation.  :(

There's a lot about why I love Double Dragon, the original in particular, that I won't be going into detail here, (I'm saving that for later.) but there's a lot I don't love about the latest cash in by some mobile phone weirdo's acquiring the Double Dragon rights and whoring out yet another rerelease of an oft-abused series. So let's get the little good out of the way  The Pro's: [quote] Online play with both the built in one and Steam remote play  The developers use a limited lives and continues system instead of letting you quarter feed.  It's Double Dragon!  Uuuh...  It's... Double Dragon 2![/quote]  The Con's: [quote] It's Double Dragon 3.  Imperfect emulation. The game now moves far too fast for calculated or strategic play.  Off controls - particularly in DD2, where my punches will register as kicks.  Some of the remixes are either bad or downright god awful. The boss music in particular was an attempt to be unique by replicating the song with game noises, but it just sounds like complete nonsense.  Achievements are broken. I got one for riding an elevator that I know I hadn't, and one for using all the weapons, which I know I hadn't. With only 15 included, you think you wouldn't be able to screw it up.  No seriously, Double Dragon 3 being included at all. This game was complete dog excrement in every regard and it being included is like including Robocop 3 with a Robocop movie set - it's just something you shouldn't do, even for historical purposes.  Double Dragon 3, while a terrible game, is another huge missed opportunity by not having the three player version[/quote]  There have been worse and stranger ports than this, but it's still a bad port. You'd be better off emulating the original 2 games in Mame, playing the NES versions or playing Double Dragon Advance on the GBA. All three alternatives I highly recommend, and if you want one on Steam, there's Double Dragon 4 and Double Dragon Neon.

I never had a chance to sit/ stand and play the original arcade games back in the day but I did have all the game on the Nintendo systems.   Those were better games. For the price point and accessibility this is a decent buy for the people that may have felt that Double Dragon Neon betrayed the franchise. Here it is the Double Dragon Trilogy on Steam! I was gleefull to say the least when I saw this was available. I remember playing the first game in the arcade way back in the 1980s so to have this legit version to play on my PC is a real treat. Can't say that I'm extremely familiar with the second and third incarnations (at least in the arcade) so there's a little something extra for me to explore there as well. Overall, not a bad port and some good nostalgia.

I was every excited about the Double Dragon Trilogy coming to steam but when I started playing Double Dragon 1 it felt like a very bad port because the game stutters a lot. It just doesn't feel right. On the contrary, Double Dragon 2 is playable very well and by far the best of the three games included. I won't even discuss Double Dragon 3 since this game is widely regarded as the worst of the three, and in my opinion maintains its reputation.  I've tried the multiplayer with a friend and it was enjoyable but when you die the game goes out of sync. I continued playing but my friend was nowhere to be found. This might just be a bug to be fixed in a later release, but for now I uninstalled Double Dragon Trilogy and hope for some much-needed improvements.

Some of you may have grew up playing Double Dragon in the Arcade, Some of you may have grown up playing Double Dragon on the NES. This game somewhat faithfully follows these ports but the original arcade GUI is missing from the original counterparts. Double Dragon 3 only gives you so many credits to spend in the weapon shop the first time around and every shop you go into the game from there on keeps saying insert the coin. If you have played the game Sonic CD on Steam you will know that this particular game was built from the ground up. This is the emulation that seems to take place in this game. Tile for Tile. Using the original sound track as digitized BGM (sound track) and not arcade native. I've seen that there have been updates to this collection to fix bugs, etc, but it's not enough to bring this collection at arcade perfection. A great game if you want to play 2 players locally on the same computer but I think this game is for die hard fans only as opposed to someone who is looking for something else to play. Grabbed this during the sale. Not a bad game but I feel kind of left hanging expecting more from this game.

Amazing,worth it for dd2 alone but dd1 is also fantastic,dd3 however is utter crap just like it always has been,the playablility in both dd1 and dd2 are super and even better than the arcade,the resolution options and filters help and the remixed music in places is to die for,wish there was a nes inclusion with this bundle but that's impossible however it's maintained it's feeling and has me swearing and kicking the shit out of the baddies while loving the music,makes me feel young again.  I would buy this even at the regular price but got it on a steam weekend deal,it's got steam achievements and trading cards,awesome remixed music and a few tweeks that make it better than the coin'op as well as filters,worth it.
