¬øQue les puedo decir acerca de este juego? Bien les contare una historia acerca de mi trayectoria en este juego. Todo comenz√≥ cuando lo conoc√≠ gracias a v√≠deos por youtube, mas concretamente gracias al youtuber hispanohablante Nexxuzworld, esto fue hace bastantes a√±os ya mas concretamente a finales de 2016, desde el d√≠a que lo conoc√≠ me pareci√≥ un juego muy entretenido y siempre lo quise jugar, as√≠ es cuando lo compre, ya ni me acuerdo, pero eso fue con mi primer pc, el cual no tenia ni tarjeta gr√°fica (Ya me imagino como sabr√°n que termino) estuve d√≠as D√çAS para instalarme lo, varios dias, cuando tenia 10 a√±os ricien cumplidos, ahi que deje mi pc encendido instalandolo... Cuando lo instale todo fue pesimo, tardo como 10 minutos en cargar el menu y me iba full trancado, cuando inicie partida todo en bajo, tardo como una hora en cargarme y cada paso que daba tarba como 4 minutos en darlo, en resumen me iba fatal... Pasan los a√±os y me consigio mi segunda pc, mucho mejor que la antigua... con una GTX 1050 con la que me hice todas las horas practicamente, resulta que al comienzo por las 20 primeras horas fui jugador solitario de servidores normales, que siempre que me conectaba terminaba raideado y me enoje con el juego, claro era un bobo y no tenia una tribu... Asi fue como comence a entrar en servidores donde la gente era muy muy poca, y con mods, de hecho los mods fue lo que me salvo casi todas las horas, ademas de mi grupo de amigos con los que fui cambiando, y alli pase como 500 horas, ya tenia 520 horas aprox... nunca mas volvi a entrar a un server oficial, porque me dan asco, pero desde entonces solamente juego solo, abosulutamente solo pero con algunos mods para entretenerme y siempre juego en los mismos 3 mapas The Island, The Center y Ragnarok, se que a√±adieron otros, pero me volvi muy inactivo estos ultimos a√±os a ark... 1000 horas que e jugado sin siquiera tener el pass, MIL HORAS sin haberme comprado el pass que tanto deseaba pero por problemas no tengo la posibilidad de tarjeta. Hasta ahora siempre e querido encontrar algun amigo en mi vida que jugara ark pero ninguno lo hace y siempre juego solo... siempre quice poder jugar otro mapas como Aberration, Extintion, pero no e podido porque no tengo le pass... pero tal vez algun dia lo compre...  Conclucion: Este juego es muy bueno, excelente lo cierto es que pesa demasiado, pero demasiado, sobre todo con los mods, pero lo recomiendo inmensamente, tambien es cierto que consume muchos requisitos, pero volvi a entrar con mi nueva pc a completar las 5 horas que me faltaban y ahora si lo pude jugar al maximo y se ve muy muy bien, desearia si alguien lee esto, que me invitara a jugar con su equipo, la verdad que ya aburre y tenga en cuenta que no tengo el pass ni ningun mapa comprado jejeje, lloro por eso pero bueno, nada que hacerle... Dejo mi discord si alguien me quiere hablar dwayne johnson#0162

This series always have the greatest potential to be amzing but the excution ruins the original design/idea of the gameplay.  This is not a enjoyable game if you play alone. I recommend you to play with your friends locally. It's very grindy and repetitive that you are required to farm resources to set up you camp site. Time managment and food allocation can be tricky issues at the beginning and no explaination is given other than Kovacs's useless 'guides' but you will get better as you progress. Besides slaying zombies there is almost nothing you can do/interact in the very empty,boring world map , you have to keep taking quests from NPCs. And the story is meaningless as well.  But still, why the hell should I recommend this boring grinder to you? It's because it supports local co-op upto 4 guys. To work together with your friends is always the best way to survive. I did spend a lot of time discussing hot to build the best camp with my friends. And the crafting system is hard-core enough, it does make sense to me. You will eventually realise that there are a hell lot of things you have to consider as a survivor and communication in co-op mode is thus become essential. Always exchange ideas with the guy sitting next to you and find a way that both players can enjoy this game. In other words, Single play? NOPE.  Co-op mode? HELL YES.

How to Survive war ein ganz gutes Spiel, da war der Name noch Programm. Aber Teil 2 ist ziemlich eint√∂nig, immer das gleiche, in fast immer gleichen Gebieten.  Bei Teil 1 musste man wirklich noch zusehen wie man √ºberlebt, weil Essen und Trinken knapp war und man immer wieder sich eine Schlafgelegenheit suchen musste. Bei Teil 2 ist das ganz anders, man wird regelrecht zu gebombt mit Essen und Trinken und Schlafen braucht man garnicht mehr.  Ich habe alleine √ºber 30 Std. gespielt und bin noch nicht fertig, gerade mal Level 25 und es soll bis Level 51 gehen. Ich wei√ü auch √ºberhaupt nicht was das Ziel des Spiels ist und was viel schlimmer ist, ich habe einfach keinen Bock mehr drauf weiter zumachen. Das Spiel geht einfach zu lange, da es nach gewisser Zeit ziemlich langweilig und eint√∂nig wird. Auch im Koop wird es leider nicht besser.  F√ºr was braucht man eigentlich ein Camp, wenn man solo spielt? Total √ºberfl√ºssig, man kann wahrscheinlich wie es aussieht, nicht einmal NPC rekrutieren bzw. aufnehmen. Sowas w√§re eine geile Idee gewesen, zus√§tzlich noch Schlafpl√§tze bauen, damit mehr Leute kommen usw..  Was mich auch ein wenig st√∂rt, das es gef√ºhlt ewig dauert, bis man bessere Waffen herstellen kann.  Die Grafik ist ansich in Ordnung, keine bis kaum Verbesserungen.

I'm not really sure what happened to this one. It lacks a lot of the charm from the original.  The weapons are one of the reasons this game feels stale, mostly you got meelee, bows/crossbows and guns. The game makes you grind A LOT to unlock weapons, missions and upgrades. The level caps each 10 levels until you finish a special mission.   The game allows you to create you own camp... which would be nice if you didnt have to grind for resourses constantly to upgrade it. If you want new weapons you upgrade the armory, Armor? the accesories workshop, Potions? the lab. There is too many structures you will need to level up to keep up and they wil eat your time farming for resourses without it being fun.  The only fun part of building your base are the missions where you must defend the comm tower from zombies and you can get creative setting defenses and traps, but its really unsatisfying anyway for all the effort it takes to setup an effective base.  In the end, I cannot recommend it, the story is not that interesting, everything is centered around Kovac, no other character shines, the customization is very limited and the game feels very stale, stages only change after doing a lot of runs and completing many missions.  I guess they focused so much in creating a crafting and level system to try to make you feel progression they forgot to make the gameplay more fun, they limited the weapon diversity and ended up making the game feel too repetitive.  I even checked ahead (youtube) to see if enemies change to be more fun or something but nope, it remains basically the same for the whole game, but they add aliens at the end to try and make it more difficult... the combat has no variation though the whole thing. Why would you do that?

Squad is an absolute gem in the world of tactical first-person shooters. As a dedicated player of the game, I can confidently say that Squad delivers an unparalleled level of immersion and strategic gameplay that few other titles can match. From the moment you step onto the battlefield, you are drawn into a world where teamwork and communication reign supreme.  One of the standout features of Squad is its attention to detail. The game's graphics are stunning, with meticulously designed environments that bring the battlefield to life. Whether you find yourself in an urban cityscape or traversing vast open landscapes, every location feels authentic and thoughtfully crafted. The attention to detail extends to the weapon mechanics and character animations, adding to the overall realism of the experience.  But what truly sets Squad apart is its unwavering focus on teamwork. In Squad, lone wolf tactics simply don't cut it. The game encourages and rewards players who communicate and collaborate effectively with their squadmates. Whether you're coordinating movements, providing covering fire, or fulfilling a specialized role, every action you take has an impact on the success of your team. The thrill of coordinating a successful assault or defending a crucial objective with a well-organized squad is unmatched.  Furthermore, Squad offers a wide variety of roles and playstyles, allowing players to find their niche and contribute to the team in meaningful ways. Whether you prefer the precision of a sniper, the versatility of a medic, or the explosive power of an anti-tank specialist, there's a role that suits your playstyle. The game's progression system also rewards dedication, providing players with the opportunity to unlock new weapons and equipment as they gain experience.  Another aspect worth mentioning is the active and passionate community surrounding Squad. The developers have fostered a dedicated player base, with regular updates and a commitment to addressing player feedback. The community is welcoming and supportive, which further enhances the overall experience.  In conclusion, Squad is a masterpiece of tactical gaming. Its stunning visuals, realistic mechanics, and unwavering emphasis on teamwork make it a standout title in the genre. If you're seeking an immersive and strategic shooter that rewards coordination and communication, look no further than Squad. Prepare for an unforgettable journey onto the virtual battlefield.

Awesome arcade game, with Awesome music and sound effects with great graphics, along with great gameplay, but very addictive arcade repetive type of Game. If you are the Gamer, that likes repetive arcade awesome games, then Nex Machina is for you:)

Nex Machina's visuals, synthwave soundtrack and intricate level design combine into a neat little shoot em up with stunning animations, and the games transitions to the next levels and worlds straight away that manages to maintain the players momentum in the action and keeps the blood pumping. was sad to see no online multiplayer though.

A well-oiled and intense twin stick shooter with beautiful visuals and voxels. Can be beaten in about a 2 hour sitting but the challenges and levels densely layered with secrets add to replayability. A great game to play and come back to in bite sized chunks. Soundtrack also stands out as the synthwave tracks are fantastic. Only real issue is the difficulty can spike randomly and some of the later stages in each level are very geared toward having the triple dash upgrade, when you die and randomly lose it, you're in for a headache. Still, very satisfying when you do complete levels and finish off bosses. I don't recommend blinking.

Man oh man this game is soooooo much fun to play, the twin stick bullet hell gameplay combined with the sick music and graphics keeps your heart beating time after time you playthrough. It's a very short game especially once you know the levels and gameplay and you can quickly blast through it, but that doesn't mean there isn't lot's of content on offer. Lot's of challenges to complete, bonus levels and the usual arcade stuff. One of the surprise hits of 2017 in my opinion.

It's not Robotron (which is one of my top five arcade games of all time), but it's probably as close as we're going to get. It's an arena shooter, it's fast and frenetic, and it's easy to let your eyes lose focus and "get in the zone."   My biggest complaint are the colors. I mean, the game is gorgeous, but there are times when so many different colors are on the screen that I can't see a bullet or enemy because they are obscured by things that are other colors.   My second biggest complaint is that it's not Robotron. C'mon Williams, or Midway, or WB (who I think owns them now), just release it on Steam already!  If you like twin sticks though, I'd recommend it. They're probably my favorite "arcadey" genre, and this is one of the best I've ever played.
One of the best games I ever played, highly recommended

Once you start to get a hang of it, you're gone. Every aspect of the game I can of think is implemented so well that it feels like a crime to buy this for its current price.  The gameplay is so addictive, pumping your blood with adrenaline on each stage and pushing you forward. Even the lowest difficulty can at times bust your balls in case you play for score. And you should. The scoring system is what gives the game its seemingly chaotic nature, which a player has to conquer. And to do that you have to come up with a strategy for each stage and for each encounter. At this point fundamental simplistic gameplay design starts to show its true potential and depth.   The next primary drive of the game is the BGM, which is of the highest quality and fits to the action perfectly. The OST absolutely deserves to be listened to separately. The are no problems with the sound effects as well - every explosion and every power-up pickup feel distinct and satysfying.  And again: it's a steal.

Nex Machina has earned its place as my favorite bullet hell shmup. It‚Äôs an extremely well-crafted game eager to blow your pants off with intense, frantic action. However, I must state that the game can seem overwhelming with the differences between difficulties. In fact, I think anything beyond ‚ÄúExperienced‚Äù will be impossible for me, but you can and do improve over time.  This game has a committed arcade design philosophy. You have numerous difficulties, different modes including co-op (with shared lives), and leaderboards for everything. The game‚Äôs Arena mode offers credits based on in-game performance used to customize your character and will occasionally throw challengers at you whose score you have to beat in order to continue growing your profile level. I definitely recommend playing some Arena so that you can purchase the bullet color that stands out the most to you if the default isn‚Äôt working out. I went with yellow which helped me process the visual information on the screen.  Single World allows you master an area, but Arcade mode is the one that puts you through the entire gauntlet. Each world only takes around 7 minutes for me to complete and there are up to 6 worlds if you play on Experienced. Rookie has 5. What keeps me coming back for me is the desire to achieve mastery due to how the game encourages an incredibly dangerous dance to keep your combo up and the fierce action constantly keeping me on the edge of my seat. You‚Äôre a very fragile being. One hit will kill you unless you‚Äôre able to collect a shield and you‚Äôre doing your best to evade hundreds of enemies and projectiles in every world.  Every world is broken into small levels. Some of those levels contain secrets which involve hidden humans to save, hidden multipliers to help build up your score, extra lives to keep you in the fight instead of using a continue, hidden targets, and secret entrances that take you to another level filled with humans to save and enemies to kill. In addition to the secrets and trying to stay alive against the relentless onslaught, you‚Äôre also trying to build up not one, but two combo meters. You have the regular score multiplier that you build up by killing regular enemies, special enemies, or finding them in the level. It doesn‚Äôt decay or go down unless you die and use up a life. You also can consider building up the human combo which works by saving a human, waiting for the combo meter to decay, and then saving another human which is very difficult to consistently do since you‚Äôre juggling so much information at once. You have to risk it to get the biscuit though and human combos are necessary to racking up huge points to make your friends look bad.  You don‚Äôt have to worry about it too much if you‚Äôre just trying to beat a higher difficulty and leaving the high score attempts for later. In fact, there are Feats (sorta like in-game achievements) for avoiding all the humans in a world. Don‚Äôt feel too overwhelmed and stick with Rookie for a while. Learn the placement of the secrets and enemy patterns before attempting the harder settings, I say.  Oh right, power-ups. They contribute to your overall effectiveness in different ways and dying means dropping one on the ground which you‚Äôll probably want to collect. You‚Äôll frequently encounter Triple Dash, Dash Explosion, Shield, Weapon Range, and Weapon Spread. Having all five at once grants you the 5-projectile spread shot instead of the 3-shot version with 4 out of 5 power-ups. There are also special weapon pick-ups with the Rocket Launcher being my favorite. Your controls involve moving with left stick, shooting with right stick, dashing with LB or L-Trigger, and using your special weapon with RB or R-Trigger. I highly recommend using a controller.  Whew, when you‚Äôre not in the zone and super focused on avoiding the cold embrace of death, you might notice the great soundtrack. Every song seems well done and fun to listen to while blasting baddies away. The neon colors also help immerse you in the retro-arcade design of the entire game. It looks good, sounds good (except for weapons which are understated a bit, but is still okay), and plays well.  Again, this game can be extremely difficult on the higher difficulties because faster enemies means faster reflexes are required and sometimes my brain can‚Äôt keep up. You can also find yourself in a situation where your run might be over because you‚Äôre caught in a death loop against a boss (remember, you lose power-ups on death and continues). It can be weirdly satisfying to take down a boss with just your basic gun and a special weapon, but that did take me around 17 continues which each one having three lives. The 6th boss didn‚Äôt even have a weapon to pick up though in its room and I just had to back out at that point. Make Rookie your best friend if you‚Äôre new to the genre or aren‚Äôt hardcore before making bold difficulty choices.  Still, I love this game very much. It‚Äôs my favorite of the genre and I recommend it with two thumbs up. It‚Äôs one of the few games that I‚Äôll leave installed indefinitely because I know I‚Äôll be shooting down thousands of more baddies in the future.

Fun but overpriced. I finished the entire campaign in less than an hour. If you like replaying the same levels over and over, you may get more mileage than I did, but I don't enjoy that kind of thing.

V-I-C-I-A-N-T-E  Excelente Game , muito bom mesmo, recomendo f√°cil de jogar e dif√≠cil ao mesmo tempo k. -Tipo de jogo que voc√™ senta para jogar um pouquinho e quando v√™ j√° se passaram dois dias kk.  eu queria muito um multplayer online

I bought this game right after it came out mostly because of the glowing reviews that it received on many of the game review websites plus it was inexpensive. It still has a Very Positive overall ranking here on Steam but buyer beware, you may not be able to play this game.   My system meets all the recommended requirements and then some however the game is basically unplayable for me and for many others. If you check the Community Discussion you will see the main stickied thread plus many others from users like myself who cannot play this game at all or beyond the first level, let alone compete in the arena season. The game will crash immediately on loading a level or after completing the first level every time.   The problem seems to be related to those who still use Windows 7 not any specific hardware. I personally did not refund because immediately after the game was released the developer, Housemarque, was aware of the problem and attempted to fix it with a few hotfixes and one main patch. Unfortunately these quick fixes did not resolve the issue and those of us who waited for them to fix it without refunding were left waiting.  We're still waiting..   Three weeks since release and after a few attempts to fix the problem failed, the developer has apparently stopped supporting the game. Less than a month after release there have been no responses or developer support for the game since July 17, 2017 other than to say they are on holiday and still monitoring the problem. They have not provided any information on their discussion or news page and have apparently stopped trying or are unable to fix their game for Windows 7 users even though it is still listed as a supported OS.   The game (what I have gotten to play of it) is a fast paced, fun twin stick acrade shooter. Perhaps one of the best in a long while but that is also what makes it so frustrating for those who cannot play. I gave them the benefit of the doubt because in the beginning they were making attempts to resolve the problem but that support seemed to end about the same time as the refund period did. If you can play the game on your system then I would recommend it however with the way the situation has played out and the developer ceasing to communicate through Steam in over a month, I can only recommend you buy to try.. and be prepared to refund quickly if you're one of the ones for whom it does not work.  This is definitely a case of Caveat Emptor and a reminder to research the Community Discussion of a game before you purchase.  Update: A new patch was released 8/25/2017 that added a new language and a new leaderboard season but no fixes.

Brief: Score: 93/100. An instant classic in the twin stick bullet hell/shoot ‚Äòem up. I recommend it to anyone looking to play a bullet hell.  Scratch that, anyone looking to play a great game should pick this up ASAP.    There are some great games in the shoot 'em up genre. And this one starts with great DNA.  I'm so happy Eugene Jarvis was involved in the development of this game. I really had settled in to being just happy with Android Assault Cactus.  But this came along and pushed the bar.  It has everything a twin stick bullet hell needs.  And the aesthetic is just wonderful.  Housemarque has really made a classic.  It saddens me that their next game, Matterfall, will not be on PC.  But they they definitely earned a preorder from me on their next game for PC.

There is also the online mode where you try to beat diffrent levels diffrent ways and you are ranked against other people.Its all about getting that perfect run from having a fast time to getting the perfect human chain and picking up all the score multiplyers.Its definatly worth buying.

Really excellent Twin Stick shooter.  Not only does the game feel good and look good, but it also has some really interesting enemy mechanics (I suspect a lot of this stems from Eugene Jarvis' input into the game), and some really well-done level design (which is somewhat rare for the genre).  Each level isn't just about reflexes, but also planning, as you have to prioritize which enemies to defeat first and figure out how to save all the humans.

Do you remember when games were exciting? When you stood in a dark room with only the glow of the machines? Crowds of people gathered and watched as you entered that weird state when it was like the game had slowed down and you were in the zone? When you left the arcade you were dripping with sweat and your senses were tingling with adrenaline ? Well this a return to these times and it's fantastic!

This was probably the worst Call of Duty Campaign I have played so far. It had a passable story but didn't have the excellent pacing that the other campaigns had. As well, I had to redo two missions twice because of a saving glitch with was super boring and didn't get some achievements like beating the campaign or beating the campaign on hardened difficulty, it could have been the activation key I bought but I find that unlikely. This game was honestly just boring and draining and is nowhere near as good as Black Ops 2 or World at War which are the two other Treyarch campaigns I've played. However, if boring it still had the excellent combat and design of Call of Duty which I find super compelling. If you are a fan of Call of Duty, I can recommend this game to you even if it was kinda forgettable.

In the 1990s, public support for gun control led then-president Bill Clinton to sign into law the 1994 Federal Assault Weapons Ban, which remained in force for ten years thereafter before expiring. Another measure by the Clinton Administration was the Brady Bill. This bill was enacted on November 30, 1993 and the main purpose was to create a waiting period for handgun purchases. The bill enacted makes a person subject to a background check when they are trying to purchase a firearm from a federal dealer, manufacturer, and also an importer. Background checks are run through the FBI and go through the National Instant Criminal Background Check System(NICS). Other features of the Brady Bill are also prohibiting transporting firearms if a person falls under certain criteria made under the bill and prohibiting firearm possession if a person has a felonious charge. A 1995 poll found that 58% of Americans were worried the government would not do enough to regulate guns, while only 35% of Americans reported worrying the government would regulate them too much.

I would oblige you to play this game with friends, it will be the best laugh you've had in a long time.  [b]9,5/10[/b]

Combination of Red Faction Guerrilla (minus the destructible environments) and Crysis. From Red Faction Guerrilla you have the driving in an arid wasteland from location to location wreaking havoc on the various factions. From Crysis you have exosuite with superhuman survivability as well as some special abilities. Its a fun game with lots to do. The technology is impressive, the open world is immense and yet there are no loading screens. The game also looks good and runs good. I have had 2 crashes in ~20hours and I'm not playing the launch build so there is still some optimization to be desired. All in all well worth it on sale.

This game is pretty okay to play. It isn't perfectly clear about what is an objective and is not.  It is a good game to zone out to while listening to something else. That being said, it crashed pretty regularly for me, and I ended up stopping playing because the game stopped working. I would attempt to launch the game and it just did not work anymore. I tried all the usual troubleshooting steps and it just refused to work. Got my basic entertainment value of out it but never looking at it again.

Good things: - graphics is nice and feels real with all the effects turned on - I'm happy I can have all the stats and guns sooner in the game. What I always hated in many games is that all the cool stuff is near the end when I actually don't use it anymore, because game ends. Not here.  Bad things: - Rage2 (release date 2019) is Mad Max (release date 2015) with better graphics. Feels the same, same way of doing things, same "cool new" things in the game (sectioned map, authority pillars vs those bandit totems in MM, convoys, cities, ....). I struggle to find 2 really new original things which MM did not had and R2 has. On the other hand I can find few cool things MM had and R2 lacks (for example upgrade of cities in MM). MM had similarly breathtaking graphics at that time and did not felt like a post apocalyptic barbie house (R2) and most of all did not crashed all the time.  - Crashes. Right now at this moment the game is unplayable. I don't know whether I actually return to the game.   Overall rating: 2 out of 5. If you did not played MM before, you will really enjoy the game and you will like it and be impressed if you wont fight with crashes all the time.

It's a fun game.  The gameplay is pleasant and satisfying, challenging on the higher difficulties, and it made me want to improve to tackle ultra nightmare. The weapons range from basic to imaginative, like the grav dart launcher that can launch your enemies off cliffs or into walls. They are all fun to use and effective. You also get some cool powers, of which I primarily relied on a force push of sorts (kills people) and a divebomb. Driving is serviceable enough, and the wasteland is big, pretty and explorable. Hidden stashes and things are hidden in a lot of places unmarked on the map, so it actually pays off to explore what might look like a place of interest off the road somewhere.  Visually the game is pretty awesome. Maybe I'm not up to date on the latest games but RAGE 2 sort of blew me away a few times with the density of details in some areas. Whole junkyard basins full of scattered items, or the dense jungle region up north. And the basic desert areas look great as well. The DLC's overgrown city produced some stunning vistas, but the main game is no slouch either. Exploring the aforementioned jungle I found remains of a city with tall buildings, and eventually climbed up to have an amazing view south onto the game world. Definitely enjoyable to just ride around, explore and take in the sights.  The story and world and all that is probably the weakest part of the game, since it's all pretty shallow and it never really draws you into the world as much as it could. The structure of the main storyline is extremely gamey and you're a cocky overpowered protagonist, so it's just there to provide justifications and excuses to have fun in the wasteland.  I haven't been playing many open world games, so I definitely enjoyed that aspect of this one, and the freedom it offered, especially when I just came out of the starting area, was still impressive and novel. If you have even a tinge of open world fatigue, I imagine RAGE 2 would lose some of its appeal. There are definitely plenty of map markers to mop up, but I had fun doing that and I think I cleared them all out. The diversity helps. There's definitely only a limited number of types of things you get at the markers, but there's enough variety both in type and in scope. Most of the locations are also pretty unique, though you will likely spot a bunch of reused smaller buildings and the like, but that's not a problem in the big picture. The locations definitely feel hand-crafted and not copy-pasted. Though there are a few notable exceptions to that, they're barely a blip on the radar.  Summing up, I would most definitely recommend this game if you're not sick of open world games. It's nothing mind-blowing (apart from some vistas you can find), but it's high quality entertainment in my opinion. Who knows, it might surprise even open world veterans. The Ghost DLC is worth it too if you enjoy the overall game.

Um FPS de mundo aberto com coisas pra fazer at√© Setubal...d√° pra fazer upgrade a tudo e mais alguma coisa, ao Ranger aos carros, motas e "coisas voadoras" , √°s armas... um mundo super rico e realmente aberto, e n√£o como o Rage original (que eu gostei bastante)... a historia continua e √© um jogo bastante divertido.

Do you like DOOM 2016? Do you love Mad Max or a Scrap Yard post apocolyptic setting? Have you always wanted these two themes in an "Open World" setting? Do you like minor sprinkled attempt of Borderlands Goofiness? Well you'll find it here in Rage 2.  DISCLAIMER: I have not played the first Rage, but given this is the second in the series, I wouldn't dare bother playing the first after what I've experienced here.  To start off, let me say that Rage 2 is a "Meh" game at worst with an "Okay" at best (6/10). The game honestly feels like a tech demo for DOOM Eternal. It has some solid gun play and movement, but I feel like it could use improvement on the fluidity of the movement & progression.  Pros:  - Solid FPS Combat System - Beautiful World and astecticly pleasing to look at - Interesting and unique vehicle types - Fun and solid Gunplay  Cons: - Boring protagonist that is super un-likeable due to his cockiness. - Under powered in the beginning with lack-luster arsenal which you have to unlock by venturing the whole map - BORING/LAME Antagonist. The "Authority" seriously? This is all we could think up? - RECYCYLED BOSSES & MINI BOSSES (Dear God save me!). - Reused Enemy types and assets everywhere you go (Insestous people roam the earth now I guess.) - Driving for 10 minutes for 2-5 minutes of combat. - Blubble Gum colour in the setting doesn't work well. - forgettable NPCs. I can't say anymore here as it's true. - Music feels half-baked or off for its setting. - boring side quests leaving you to focus on the campaigne. - Is a grind to push yourself through unless you're here for the combat. - Vehicle movement feels stiff and you easily find yourself going off-road and blowing up your vehicle randomly after getting out. - Just needed more time for debugging?  All in all the game is "Okay". That's all I can say. I wish there was a side ways thumb option because this is definitely a Mixed feeling review. I like the game, but equally dislike it. Lets hope this IP is set aside for a while.

Despite the long pauses in action as you trek from objective to objective the action provided is fast, fluid, and fun. If you're like me and you've played enough DOOM 2016 to have developed an itch for fast paced and mind numbing action RAGE 2 will satiate your blood thirst adequately in the meantime till DOOM Eternal is released. The only real complaint I have about this game is the over-abundance of menu items and the unnecessary quantity of things to care about. Going from brutally lighting goons up and then maliciously torching muties is like taking an empty can of soda, heating it up, then dunking it into ice-cold water to watch it shrivel up and implode. I don't care much for leveling up the skills presented or collecting cars and other items. I just want to kill monsters and bad guys, something that DOOM 2016 did do splendidly. The game would have been drastically better if instead of having to scour the wasteland searching for skills, abilities, weapons, and items, they simply just gave you the arsenal and set you loose on a path of total destruction and carnage. While this isn't the case and all the "stuff" does detract from the game, it is not so much so as to make it bad.
Cringy cutscenes were puting me off this game... but after playing some time i really like it.

review: Devo dire che giocando civ dal primo capitolo ero un p√≤ scettico da questa nuova versione di civilization. Molte recensioni negative e molte critiche... Che dire. Civ 5 √® superiore ma in questa versione (Rise and fall) vi sono dei particolari che mi piacciono molto. La relegione per esempio. O i boost per le tecnologie e le culture. La parte delle et√† dell'oro pensavo fosse una problema ma si √® rivelato molto interessante. L'unica cosa da verificare √® purtroppo una delle pi√π importanti: la AI. completamente senza senso. game: Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
review: An update that brings Civ6 into the same ballpark of Civ5. 6 started of slow and the base game was pretty lackluster, this update makes it worth playing, as opposed to just playing 5, the loyalty is fun, and the ideas of free cities makes placing cities a strategic choice rather than just wherever is a good spot. Hell you might even go to war, to make sure you get the right place. Governers is a great addition, adding to the little details of running your country. The Golden/Dark ages are an interesting feature, that adds another level of complications and challenges. Managing your ages is important. In some ways, it stops snowballing, as getting a lot of achievements leads to a golden age, but most of the time in my experience, a dark age soon follows a golden one. All in all the update is a fantastic addition.

review: Muito bom! O sistema de eras √© melhor que o do Civ V e os governadores realmente mudam o jogo. As emerg√™ncias n√£o mudam muito.  Mudei para "n√£o recomendo" porque todas as mec√¢nicas dessa expans√£o agora est√£o inclu√≠das em Gathering Storm.

game: Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
review: A bit overpriced. Get it on a sale. But.. I think it adds a lot to the core game. The loyalty is a nice additio and adds another dangerous way of loosing (or winning) cities, and the refined religion is much better. I also like the governors. The dark/normal/golden age is a nice addition while it could do with some refining and finetuning ofc, but generally, I like that expansion and thinks it adds a lot, and nowadays I can't really play Civ6 without Rise and Fall.  Looking forwards to see what Gathering Storm will add when it drops!

game: Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
review: Regarding Rise & Fall. Like all Civilization releases it's critical to pickup the expansions. No change here.   When R&F launched it had some fundamental flaws. For instance the new Golden/Dark/Heroic Age system was neat but kind of ruined the end game. At the time it would leave you eternally stuck on whatever Age you were last on when you clicked the ‚ÄòOne more turn‚Ä¶‚Äù option. As someone who can easily drop dozens of hours into Civ even after the main objectives are done this ruined it for me. If you were stuck in a Dark Age you were forever at a disadvantage. On the flipside if you were stuck in a Golden/Heroic Age you were always OP.   The reason I bring up the example above is because Firaxis took the feedback and directly fixed the issue in a follow up patch. This is an improvement over how they seemed to be handling the base game in 2017.      Civ VI review pasted from main store page below...  "Changing my review from negative to positive after a year and a half worth of work on the game. Like most Civ releases the base game is usually in rough shape. It usually isn't until it gets an expansion released that it starts to really grow into what it promised to be. I'd still like more developer communication regarding known bugs and the patch/hotfix deployment process still isn‚Äôt great (compared to V). It's really starting to look like the primary way to play Civ if not already. Pick it up (and the expansions)."

game: Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
review: I've played this DLC for a bit, when I first tried it I hated it.  Losing my cities over loyalty, not being able to settle in sertain places.  But as I played it more and more I began to enjoy it, a lot.  Now I can't imagine playing a game without it.  You just have to adjust to the new style of play, once you understand how the loyalty system actually works it becomes a hell of a lot of fun.  My only complaint is the emergencies and how no civ ever seems to join in on them.  Apart from that it's a must have.

When the winter sale started, I bought R&F, and I relearned how amazing this DLC truly is. You don't really understand how muc this DLC is awesome until you go back to the base game for some time and then return to R&F. 9/10

Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
review: While this expansion doesnt add a lot in terms of gameplay mechanics, I have found in my games that it changes how I play signifigantly, which in my mind makes up for the lack of content.  I do not have a lot of multiplayer experience with this expansion as few of my friends have it, so most of what I say is applicable to single player.  First off, loyalty.  This new mechanic makes it basically impossible for any of the AI to forward settle (this also affects your ability to forward settle, and while it can still be done it is a much more costly move than it was in vanilla).  If an AI does choose to forward settle you, you can expect a new city close to your capital, that you incur no warmongering penalties for taking.  It makes expanding take more thought to ensure you dont waste a settler, and it makes espionage a bit more interesting as the game progresses.  I should note that my games dont normally go past the early modern era so I cannot speak to how it affects the late game, but it makes the early game a lot more interesting, especially early game war as a captured city can rebel if you dont take out the capital fast enough, making for some interesing combat scenarios.  Next, the ages.  I would say this is the weakest part of the expansion (also it is incompatible most mods that alter tech/civic costs, so if you like to play with those mods make sure they are updated/made for R+F) as it adds the least to the base game.  In singleplayer ages dont really make a major difference, although I can see some potential for multiplayer with certain aspects like Dark Age policy cards, which give really strong bonuses at a great cost.  Whether you get a dark age or a golden age is supposed to affect the loyalty of your cities, but ive never seen it make a noticable difference.  One quick thing that has been noted in other reviews is that you cannot play the R+F civs in vanilla, so if you wanted R+F for the civs but dont want the other parts, than I would recommend looking for an alternative in the workshop.  That being said I love the civs they added, as they are all very unique and play differently than vanilla civs.  Also some vanilla civs have minor alterations due to some of the gameplay changes.  I would say that the new civs are my favorite part of the expansion.  There are also new wonders but they are pretty standard, just new wonders, both manmade and natural.  The new government system is probalby the best part of this expansion after the new civs.  Getting governors really changes up how you play, and they give bonuses that change how the game is played at all difficulties.  My only gripe is how one of the governors will give you envoys if you assign them to a city state, so you basically have to appoint them in order to stay competive before you get spies.  Government legacies are now policy cards that you get upon building the Government Plaza, a new district that has buildings you can contruct that will alter your playstyle.  You can also use a government legacy whle still having that government (+8 Oligarchy combat strength anyone?).  Alliances have been reworked and I really like what they did, as it makes international trading better than it was before, but it's still debateable whether or not to focus on internal trade.  They made it so there are 5 different types of alliance that each have 3 levels, so you are now limited to the amount of them you can have.  I like to play persia so I havent seen too much of the trading aspect, but it is definitely a nice addition.  There are also emergencies, which are basically temp alliances, but my games rarely go long enough for me to have anything to say about them.  Overall If you like the new civs, or are looking to spice up your civ games and change the way you approach civ 6, then this expansion does a good job, definitely get it on sale though.

game: Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
review: One of the worst parts about civ 5 and 6 was when the AI would put a crappy city right in the middle of your empire and the only solution was to declare war and raze it.  Rise and Fall introduces a loyalty system and works very similar to civ 4.  Each city exudes loyalty pressure to all citys within 9 tiles, the closer and bigger the city the more loyalty it produces.  So when that pesky AI plants a city right in the middle of your territory to steal a strategic resource just sit back and watch their city become your city.

game: Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
review: The new civilizations are unique and interesting to play, and one of my favorite from civ 5, morocco, plays very similar to the Cree indians in R&F as they rely on trade routes to thrive. The expansion adds more in depth gameplay although it can be confusing at times makes it easier to min/max everything and allows comebacks from being behind with the new dark/golden/heroic ages, which rewards good players, and if you not doing to hot, then gives you a chance to slingshot back towards the top to have a chance.  TLDR: The expansion adds way more depth, mechanics, AI developement, and interesting new civs we havent seen before.

game: Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
review: I see that the opinions are controversial about this expansion. I think that, overall,  it is just OK. It does not turn an already good game into a masterpiece, but it does not make it worse, either. Some of the new additions are better than others, obviously, but this is mostly a matter of taste. I think that it is exceedingly expensive, but this is the current policy of many companies: to milk the customers as cows. As for me, I am a cow reasonably happy, but I am aware of being a cow.

game: Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
review: Rise and Fall is an almost essential upgrade if you already own Civilization VI and plan to continue playing it or its other upcoming expansion, Gathering Storm. It's worth its price just as it is, but if you have any doubts or your wallet is experiencing a Dark Age, wait for a sale or suitable bundle purchase.  The expansion is not without some shortcomings: Loyalty and Casus Belli systems both seem too forgiving or too punishing depending on which end of the influence you are. I found it very difficult to ever capture cities by pushing neighbouring citizens loyal to my civilization, AI seems to receive some kind of bonus for it, but I'm not sure if that's accurate. Both the loyalty system and Casus Belli declarations of war are still much needed additions to base game though, and they may become better with the next expansion, or they may break entirely, which has sometimes happened to updated features of the game. Emergencies are also not utilized to their fullest capacity, but they never actually hurt anyone's play.  Ultimately the expansion is almost worth it for the new civilizations and leaders alone (I hoped there had been more leaders for existing civilizations, but the overall selection available currently is more than sufficient), increasing nation variety, while era types and governors add new and fresh depth to long-term strategic gameplay of the original base game.   Civilization VI: Rise and Fall - Full Loyalty.

game: Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
review: A+ highly recommended. I see so many negative reviews, but I just can't agree with them. I've been playing Civ since the very beginning - many , many years ago. Civ VI + Rise & Fall is an AWESOME addition to the family. I'm 80 hours in and loving it. Looking forward to many more hours of fun with this game. If you love Civs of years past, you will enjoy this game just as you have the others. The game play is IMO very well thought out & expanded upon. Don't listen to the naysayers. This game + Rise & Fall rocks.

game: Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
review: Lien de critique originale: https://steamcommunity.com/id/stmaryal/recommended/289070/  Ah Rise and Fall, quand j'ai vu l'annonce je me suis r√©jouie de voir que Firaxis √† √©couter √ßa communaut√© et nous propose cette extension, qui a des qualit√© et des d√©faut.   Partie 1: le nouveaux contenu  Hormis les nouvelle civilisation qui sont de qualit√© variable, l'extension rajoute divers nouveaut√© au jeu comme l'√¢ge d'or (qui est bien) et l'√¢ge sombre (qui est un plaie), mais aussi l'apparition des villes libres qui peut cr√©er des friction entre joueur humain, le pourquoi la ville se rebelle est bien int√©grer et ne fais pas tache car il est possible de r√©cup√©rer la ville si on se d√©brouille bien.  Partie 2: les points n√©gatif  Bon, les points n√©gatifs sont assez simple, l'impossibilit√© de jouer avec les civilisation de l'extension sans le mode (la r√®gle) Rise and fall, ne pas pouvoir customiser soit m√™me les r√®gle comme enlever l'√¢ge sombre et faire que les villes libres ne soit pas constamment en guerre, bref ils y en a d'autre mais ils sont surtout dut au jeu de base.  Conclusion:  Cette extension est plut√¥t r√©ussie, le prix est assez raisonnable malgr√© que selon moi il aurais du cout√© 5 voir 10 euros de moins, personnellement je vous conseillerais d'attendre que vous ayez un peu d'argent de coter pour acheter cette extension, je vous propose de me faire connaitre votre avis dans les commentaire (je ne suis pas devin et connaitre l'avis des gens m'int√©resse).

game: Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
review: This is a short review for Rise & Fall DLC, not the base game.  Long story short: awful. We've been sold negligible amount of content for a full price of AA title. New nations? Modders make dozens of them - for free. New mechanics? When you play through a couple ages you suddenly realize that there is NO NEW MECHANICS, as "new" mechanics from Rise&Fall brings nothing to the game - except for feeding itself. E.g. you select a focus in age 1 that helps you get points faster so you can get a better age at age 2...so you get get even more points and have higher chance at better age at age 3, et ceteral.  Actual effect on GAME ITSELF is less than negligible.  There is, however, major feature of the DLC: bugs. Dozens of them. Air carrier armadas are bugged, Fighters are bugged. Unit switching is bugged. Hell, what is NOT bugged? And packed with bugs comes yet another feature: you're basically unable to discuss them on forums - once you try you,  you get your posts deleted by moderators with absurd excuses for reasons.  Recap: you'd be not happy if you had received this DLC for free. You should NEVER pay for it as it's not worth it, and won't be worth it unless all bugs are fixed and DLC itself  is on a 99% sale. Absolutely do not recommend it.

game: Sid Meier's Civilization¬Æ VI: Rise and Fall
review: Bought this DLC in the latest deep discount Steam Sale and am impressed. There's plenty here to reinvigorate the game and though I've logged only about 25 hours so far, I've more than gotten my money's worth out of the $20 USD I spent for the DLC. I look forward to playing it more.

The other smaller features are nice, but not worth puting yourself through the pain of experiencing city loyalty and dark ages to try them out. What makes dlc even worse is you can't even play as any of the civilizations from this dlc unless you play in this dlc's game mode. All I wanted was to play as Scotland, but no, if I want to do that I need to put myself through a not fun game - the rise and fall game mode.

Wieder mal ein Klicker. Meiner Meinung nach einer der besseren. Es gibt immer wieder, neue Verbesserungen freizuschalten. Auch der Kauf im Ingame-Shop ist nicht unbedingt n√∂tig. F√ºr Clicker-Fans ein gutes kostenfreies Angebot. Zum Testen allemal wert.

Rather than click repeatedly to earn things, you can hold a button down, which is great for those that use a track pad instead of a mouse, or an auto-clicker.  And...that's the only good thing about this game that I can think of. Graphics are well-made, but uninteresting.  Progress is a slog, with mandatory wait times for things like boats and libraries even after you're able to build things in seconds. There's occasional audio errors, and no way to adjust music and sound effect volume other than "on" or "off". And I don't like how pop-ups for the microtransactions kept appearing before my 1st New Game+.  There are so many free-to-play Clicker games out there, some of which are actually decent. This one's just boring. Avoid it.

Castle Clicker is delightful with smooth animation and detailed, rich artwork. If you like clickers, this one is worth the time. While purchase is absolutely not necessary for success, I do recommend picking up a bundle to support the developer, who is attentive to the players. Upgrades and events are included.  ***This is not a speed clicker. You are not trying to see how fast you can give yourself carpal tunnel.***  The mechanics are easy. Build, ship, mine, trade, repeat. When you are done, reset or sell... or both.  Achievements (quests), treasure chests and artifacts move you further along and help you click. Auto-clicker is upgradeable. Yes, the gems you need are already in the game. If you cannot figure something out, check the discussions. Great guides are available, along with opposing play styles.  So far, everything I could list as a con has been worked out in a bug fix or explained to me because I was doing it wrong. Thus far, this is one of my favorite ways to spend some relaxing time in a game.

I have played many clickers, this is one of the good ones in my opinion. The theme is like a city management game, where you click to speed up things. You have to pay workers wages to make them work, so you don't have to click.  You have to make choices. Every level up give sa boost to something, gathering, building, sailing etc. Clicking and workers are separate. I like leveling up clicking mining power and woker building power.  Ships are used for finding new mines, exploring cities, trade or finding treasures. Each ship after the first one has its own stats. You can choose faster base speed, more sailors or more capacity.   Since it's a free game, it's definitely worth a try.
A nice game to have on the other screen while you play something else. Takes more clicking than most idle-games but you can progress without clicks as well. Nicely made and idle enough :)

For .99, this "free" game doubles your click speed and there's even more stuff for sale.  I'd snag it to reduce time load of the game. However, as of my review, this is sadly yet another port to Steam without functional in-game purchases.  You'd think they'd have an interest in getting that working.  It's a relaxing casual clicker otherwise. The pacing's perfect for watching a show or housework and just checking in on the game. I like the game but there a few bugs I would like to point out: - When the game crashes certain events are not stored correctly. For example the I had built a Iibrary and got the ability to create a university, I built two of those. A few days later there was a power outage, so the game was unexpectedly closed. I built another library and unlocked... University! That should have been observatory! But the cost for the library increased any way. - Another example is that the paper lady (the one that you have to pay 25 gems when starting a new game plus 1) pops up after each crash asking whether I want to get her help for 0 gems. This is probably related to the previous bug. - When the ships arrived and you send them again via the notification -> updates, it is sometimes not possible to click the notifications button, it just won't react. You'll have to click another menu item first. - Master of Time achievement is broken! I used each time stone at least twice by now. Prove is in the stats page.  There are more trivial bugs, but these are the most imprtant, I may add more later.

One thing I like about this game, since my finger gets tired, is I don't have to click.  I hold my mouse button and it clicks automatically. As far as the game play, it is a lot of fun because it is a building game and not just a clicking came.  You build ships to explore for more mines, towns or treasure.  You can also sell your resources to the towns you find.  You build different buildings which open up even more buildings.  It is so much more enjoyable than just clicking on something to make money as most clicker games are.  The one negative I have is when there is more than two things on a list I can't seem to scroll down to see the others.  This is in the building window, mine window, worker window, etc.  Some of the windows let you select my category but if there are more then two in the category than I can't scroll.  I hope this gets fixed because it is annoying but playable.

I don't write a lot of reviews, but this one deserves it.  It deserves better than mixed reviews for a free clicker. If clickers aren't your thing you should move on.  I have been playing many free clickers since I have been sick, but this one tops them. In game achievements/rewards make the game interesting, while the tiers/and resource collection makes the game more diverse than the standard clicker.  There are many buildings to build, ships to send out, and workers to assign.  You gain bonuses by leveling up through collecting resources and building, while your worker classes can also gain levels to make them more efficient.  The dev is active in Steam discussion and accepts feedback.

After a couple of hours of playtime I decided to give this game a proper review. First of all I want to say that the negative reviews here are most likely from people who didn¬¥t give this game a proper look.  [u]What this game is about:[/u] Castle Clicker is an Idle/active Clicker game like the other Clicker games you probably know already. You click on things and get something. This game is about collecting ressources and then building stuff with collected ressources.   [u]PROS: What this game offers:[/u] [list] [*] Building and increasing ressource pools as you progress in this game [*] Sending ships out into the unknown to discover new mines (Stone/Coal/Clay/Iron/Gold/Marble) [*] Sending ships out to discover unknown towns, so you can trade your ressources for gold/ressources [*] Sending ships out to discover treasures to find chests which can contain great stuff (Ingame currency, many ressources) [*] You can play actively with clicking (or get an autoclicker lol) and you can assing up to 100 workers at the same time,  which come from your population, to do the job for you while you watch or when you go offline [*] New Game+ feature when you achieve building all the buildings, which results in a "soft reset" where you can build better buildings : Note - you keep your ressources and all your buildings, but you can build improved versions of buildings which give you much more ressources etc. [*] A level up mechanic where you can decide what bonuses you get from leveling [*] A sort of Skill Tree where you can decide which workers (Sailors, Miners, Builders, Refiners) improve, meaning your Idle workers get more stuff done, so you can skill to fit your personal playstyle [*] There are microtransactions BUT they really don¬¥t give that much of an advantage (only the once buyable Support Coin for 3.99$ gives +50% XP and 25% faster ships, both stats are available while leveling up or can even be pushed with buildings) [*] You get a lot of Gems (Premium Currency) for free while tapping [*] There are certain types of Gemstones which let you boost worker efficiency and even stones that can change mines (example: you can turn Stone Mines into any other ressource when you unlocked them), there is even crazy stuff like Timestones which lets you fast forward time up to 1 day (really neat, got 2 already for free) [/list] [u]CONS: What are the cons?[/u] [list] [*] Can feel very slow to get into the game [*] Not knowing what to level up can result in frustration once you know what¬¥s better suited for your playstyle (NOTE: there is an option to Reskill your worker levels by using 15 Gems, it¬¥s not hard to get those) [*] As with every Clicker game there is a certain "Wall" at some time, meaning you will be stuck at some point until you overcome this hurdle [*] When using an Autoclicker the game seems to cap at 10 clicks per second [/list]  So far that¬¥s what i¬¥ve experienced in this game. Give it a try if you¬¥re interested! Hope this helps!

We're used to questmarkers telling us where to go, what to loot and a leveling system that makes us the strongest of them all in the end. Outer Wilds advances by the player leveling up. You gain more knowledge each time, fly your ship with more finesse and in the end you decide how to "end" the game. Even your thinking changes, You suddenly do things because you solved puzzles earlier and it became instinct to try certain approaches. Even the music played will change your behaviour and there are certain melodies that start as a beautiful tune and turn into a bittersweet memory. The ending will not make sense to somebody who hasn't played it, but will have a surprising emotional impact when you do.

I looked everywhere but I was still missing something but being 11 hours in and unable to figure it out for myself I decided to stop.  It's an amazing exploration game which fills you with a sense of wonder and mystery but for me it got tedious as I wasn't finding anything and I'd explored all the leads the game gave me. I did try use a guide to get me looking in any direction in my last hour but I had already done things in the guide but then missed one part. it made me feel like I'd have to go through an entire area searching for something I missed and the enjoyment at that point was all but gone!

I saw the reviews and I got curious about the game, I saw how it even helped people to get through rough times but..... It wasn't for me personally, and I don't recommend it unless.  1. You like space games and difficult controls 2. You have A TON, like A TON of patience, because this game will make you get stuck many times scratching your head. It has a "good" story but the story is buried in so much frustrating exploration (it isn't even fun exploration in my opinion)  If you want a good sci fi, exploration game I would recommend much more Prey, that game has also a lot of mistery, better space suit controls, you have characters you can connect to, the ending is great, the combat is also great and the enemies are a good challenge to beat with the weapons you begin to unlock along the way. It is also an exploration game that invites you to jump and jetpack through space, to investigate and discover what happened around you.  So for me, the problems on why I didn't like the game are these:  FIRST, the controls on the spaceship and the space suit are really uncomfortable, literally uncomfortable, I know they are "realistic" but in my opinion that doesn't equal to fun.  SPOILERS for a game mechanic.  SECOND. The loops I begin every time make me feel like I have to rush through each loop to make anything done, and I hate that feeling of getting rushed, and there were times where I searched everywhere but the loop ended and I started from the beginning frustrated. Also, the space fuel and oxigen adds to that rush feeling and it made me feel both rushed, bored and frustrated to play each loop.   END OF SPOILERS  The game began to lose my interest as more time passed and no matter the "discoveries" I made, instead of making me feel accomplished like Dark souls games after beating a hard boss, or ending a good story game or visual novel, with this game, each time I got a new, minimum bare bones of information, I just wanted the game to go to the credits.  There's not much to do in the game more than use the space suit and spaceship, and you have a translation tool that gives you the tiniest bits of information until you "get the pieces" together..... the other  tools are ok but boring in my opinion.  So that's it. The story I guess it's good but the game got sooooo boring after hours of being stuck (I never used a single tutorial to finish it, I did it all by myself) and hours of just exhaustion from being done with the controls that by the end of the game I was more glad instead of "enlightened" for finishing the game. I also never cared about anyone in this game, because there's no one for the most part, and the messages some uhmmm, let's say "ghosts"  leaved behind are...meh, again, just minute discoveries that felt more like a chore rather than something that feed my curiosity.   I recommend this game for those people who want a lenghty good story, but be careful with the controls as in my opinion, they're bad, very bad. realistic, but bothersome, use controllers if you can also. Hopefully you don't get as annoyed like me with the game, I guess it was not for me, but still, I cannot recommend this game but for some people who really like space  sci fi games; or the game is on  some heavy discount so you can check it for yourslef like I did out of curiosity, beware of boringness though. Aside form that, I recommend you to check prey instead.

This just might be the game of the decade. I realize puzzlers aren't for everyone but if you like exploring and feeling perplexed awe, do not pass this up. It is beautiful in so many ways. I wish I could erase it from my mind and experience it blind all over again.

Ce jeu n'est pas un simple jeu d'aventure. Ce jeu est un voyage, un po√®me, une merveille. Quel plaisir de jouer √† ce genre de jeu loin de ces triple A, ici oublie toutes tes convictions et laisse toi submerger par la beaut√© et l'intrigue du jeu. Si je pouvais le refaire sans le conna√Ætre, je foncerais alors si tu te demandes encore si tu vas l'acheter, n'attends plus et fonce. Envole toi vers ces quelques plan√®tes toutes diff√©rentes les unes des autres mais √† la fois li√©es par un m√™me secret et surtout sois d√©boussol√© par tout ce qui t'arrive. No words can adequately describe how this experience has impacted me.

Outer Wilds combines nice puzzles, a fascinating story, "treasure hunting" and a simple flight simulator into a rather appealing experience. It does to the secret-hunting of 90's Doom what Doom 2016 did to the violence of 90's Doom. Although the flight simulator itself is simple, the challenges in it - accounting for quirky curvature of space as well as navigating in rather tight orbits - makes for an interesting challenge as well.

This is probably one of the best games I've played in a long time. A wonderful exploration of a solar system whilst stuck in a time loop, discovering all there is to know about an ancient and mystical race that came before you. The time sensitive nature of the game made it frustrating at times, but that just made it all the more rewarding when you finally did what you intended.  A friend of mine said he wished he could wipe his memory just so he could play it again. He's not wrong.

An easy recommendation. A great exploration game with a lot of heart, but just because it's an exploration game doesn't mean it's a walking simulator. This game has some really good challenges and there's plenty of depth to the gameplay experience. One of my favorite games I've ever played

Ein genial innovatives Spiel. Es hat mir richtig Spa√ü gemacht immer wieder in mein kleines Raumschiff zu steigen und die Geheimnisse des kleinen Sonnensystems zu erkunden, in dem die Handlung dieses Spiel abl√§uft. Kein Kampf, kein Inventar, keine F√§higkeiten die es zu ergattern gibt - einfach nur Geheimnisse erkunden bis sich alles zu einem gro√üen Puzzle zusammenf√ºgt der einem aufzeigt, wie man das Spiel "gewinnt" (was im Prinzip innerhalb von nur 20 Minuten machbar w√§re wenn man alles vorher schon wei√ü). Die Spielwelt die es zu erkunden gibt ist dabei so phantasievoll gestaltet wie man sie von den besten Walking Simulatoren wie What Remains of Edith Finch oder The Vanishing of Ethan Carter her kennt - mit einzigartigen und skurrilen Welten.  Wo viel Licht ist, ist aber auch ein wenig Schatten. Die fehlende Sprachausgabe rei√üt einen etwas aus der Immersion. Die Zero-G Raumschiffsteuerung ist f√ºr unge√ºbte Spieler Gew√∂hnungssache und manche Geschicklichkeitssequenzen nerven etwas, vorallem da man sie ggf. einige Male im Spiel wiederholen muss. Auch ist bei dem ein oder anderen R√§tsel ein leichter Zeitdruck dabei, auch wenn das Spiel grunds√§tzlich nicht schwer ist und gelegentliche Fehltritte werden in dem Spiel mechanisch bedingt etwas st√§rker bestraft als bei vielen anderen Spielen.  Trotzdem kann ich nur jedem, der was f√ºr freie Ekundungs-Spiele mit interessanter Geschichte √ºbrig hat dieses Spiel nur uneingeschr√§nkt empfehlen.

This game is as good as the hype says it is. This is a life changing experience.   There's something to be said about the difference between a 60 hour game with good experiences versus a 20 hour game with unforgettable experiences. The leap in design between this and its contemporaries is comparable to Half-Life amidst arena shooters and Portal among puzzle games.  Truly, I've never played something so full of discovery in just 20 hours, and that is in large part to the game's primary conceit: The 22 minute loop.   To those that do not know game design theory, almost all gameplay can be broken down into 'loops' of action by the player. Famously, Halo developers (notably Jaime Griesemer of Highwire Games) used the phrase "32 seconds of fun" to describe Halo's combat loop; fans of The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim describe the loop of that game as "Quest, explore, kill, repeat" with both derision and praise. Outer Wilds takes the concept and runs with it, asking 'what would happen if the game's loop was 22 minutes long, while also being diegetic and story encompassing?'   Now, this isn't a spoiler--avoid all spoilers and guides, by the way; this is a very rewarding experience to go in blind for--but your character is stuck in a loop of their home star going supernova. The gameplay loop, in a design sense, is to explore this galaxy and find a way to stop this event from happening. As far as in-game progress goes, the only guidelines you have for progress is a shipboard computer that catalogs all discoveries made across all loops. The defining feature that provides a throughline for your journey is [i] you, [/i] as in you the player, and your accumulated knowledge of this system. That's it. No hand-holding, few hints, just your ability to piece together this quite expansive story non-linearly. It is one of the most cathartic and rewarding experiences of discovery I have had in my career as a game developer and my time as a player of games.   That's not even talking about the story or the music. There's a reason the latter has a DLC purchase option. It's good. So good it'll be on your spotify, your phone, or whatever means you have of music listening for the next week or longer. There are works so moving in this that it encapsulates entire themes of this game and brings me near to tears in just a few notes. If you're reading this review after playing, you know the particular song I'm talking about. The story, in turn, is so complicated and fascinating that you could spend days just piecing together the histories of an extinct alien race, your own contemporary compatriots, and the reason for this catastrophe into a comprehensive timeline. Though you only have 22 minutes of exploration per each loop, it feels like there are at the very least sixty times that amount of time worth of content and you'll end up wanting to explore every moment. You will want to meet every character multiple times just to see how they change throughout the loop. Those interactions are so powerful, so thematically justified, that they will stay with you for months. If you want my advice, talk to Chert on Ember Twin at different points in the loop and your discoveries. Their arc is both the most subtle and most profound in this entire medium of expression.  Someone before me said this is a once in a lifetime game and I have to agree. This game is art. Pure and simple. To expand on that, though, this is a once in a [i] genre [/i] type of art. I mean that as, if you were to quantifiably define an entire means of expression in art, such as certain modes of paintings, scores of music, or films, you may choose a selection of works to do so; The Outer Wilds is that for video games. Genre defining. Not as a buzzword, not as marketing, but as a description as to what is possible with this medium. If a cynic told you games cannot be art, this is the  example as to why that cynic is wrong.  No matter the price you pay, this game is worth it. I payed for it on a winter sale and it is the only game I've ever purchased that made me wish I payed more. Play it, explore the Hearthian system time and time again, and learn something about yourself in perhaps the greatest video game of all time.

It is pretty hard for me to dislike a game. However, I disliked outer wilds. I returned it because the controls are annoying. It isn't because they were necessarily confusing, I just didn't like how they functioned, leading to the return I made. I have played games like firewatch, csgo, overwatch, BOTW(& other legend of zelda games), minecraft, just cause, subnautica, far cry, gta, antichamber, slime rancher, half life/portal, rainbow 6, for honor, etc. so i have some experience with 3D world games and their controls whether they be third person or first. For some reason the developers of this game just didn't hit the mark on their controls unfortunately and it really bugged me.  That being said, I only played around 30 minutes of the game and didn't get a full picture of the game's complex worlds, which I'm sure are very interesting.

Dans l'ensemble, les points positifs : - une histoire vraiment tr√®s intelligente avec des r√©v√©lations poignantes et une fin √©pique - des moments carr√©ment √©mouvants et dr√¥les - une tr√®s bonne jouabilit√© y compris au clavier - un gameplay franchement sympa (on peut se d√©placer facilement, on ne meurt pas √† chaque chute) - des m√©canismes de jeu et des puzzles super innovants (chaque plan√®te a son fonctionnement, je n'en dis pas plus...) - un syst√®me de journal qui garanti de ne quasiment jamais √™tre bloqu√© - des PNJ d√©bonnaires - une tr√®s bonne BO - des graphismes plaisants qui ne font pas la course au r√©alisme (oui oui, je trouve √ßa bien de ne pas faire souffler mon ordi pour rien, si je veux voir de vrais arbres, je sors faire une balade)  Les seuls points n√©gatifs : - une zone du jeu o√π le d√©placement souris + clavier rend l'√©preuve hautement difficile, mais faisable - quelques "√©nigmes" o√π j'aurais aim√© un petit indice car la logique ne m'a pas paru √©vidente et j'ai d√ª regarder sur internet (deux fois, donc √ßa va)  Voil√† donc si vous avez envie de d√©couvrir un autre univers et de faire le zouave dans une fus√©e, foncez !

For $24.99 you can play a piece of art that will break your heart.  I adore watching others play Outer Wilds, just to recapture a piece of what it felt like to point my ductaped little deathtrap of a spaceship into the dark places that I feared more than I understood and to do what Feldspar would do: floor it.  I sat in front of my computer and cried at the end. Six months later I'm still crushed that I can never play it again. There's no better use for your computer than playing this game.

This is the type of game that 20 years down the line if you ask any developer what their inspiration was, they will most likely point to this game.   This game is so perfect because it just puts you in without context, and lets your curiosity drive you. No one told you to go to that planet first, but you just wanted to see what it was. This game is all about that feeling of discovery, and it pulls it off exceptionally well. It gets even more interesting once you find out some scraps of the story, and start trying to piece them together. Clues will lead you hopping from planet to planet, finding new things where you thought nothing could be.   Overall, this game is a masterpiece, and the sense of discovery drives it home.

Arguably one of the most satisfying games I've ever played.  I wouldn't say it requires it, but going in with minimal expectations and a mind that appreciates the simplicity of discovery will leave you breathless at the end. I'm dumbfounded on so many levels as I write this. The music, the scale of the solar system, the controls, the story.. they're all incredible.   If you're fascinated by space and time, the dynamics of quantum states, or simply enjoy sandbox type games, this one really would be a shame to miss out on.

This game is best played blind. Don't do too much Googling.  I should start this review by saying that there are people this game is not for. Outer Wilds has been compared to a walking simulator. I completely disagree with this stance, but can agree that there are many points in the game where you will: - Allow the game to take you through the story - Simply walk/fly around and admire the sights/atmosphere - Explore areas just because they look interesting/haven't been seen yet - Read and ponder in-game text - Put down the controller for a bit just to think through puzzles - Feel accomplishment by working through a grand mystery - Work around a timer (Though the timer has no punishment and is very lax. But, you may lose a few minutes of gameplay or feel pressured occasionally)   If you can't get behind the above, the game may not appeal to you. You will be doing the above for most of the ~30 play through, and if a chill gaming session will bore you, this game may too. You won't be shooting at things. You won't have an adrenaline filled session. You won't be hopping out of your seat.  Now, why is Outer Wilds one of the best games I've ever played? If you find that you are the type of player who will: - Get engrossed into a great story - Allow yourself to feel discovery, freedom, fear, and dread - Appreciate a very intricate and atmospheric experience - Enjoy exploring space, as well as a large/busy game world - Thrive in non-linear, open gameplay - Take your time in the game environment and be patient - Enjoy reading text and using what you've learned to connect the dots  There is a lot here for you. Download and play right away. Thank me later.   A good comparison is Subnautica, which had a similar exploration theme. Still, the story and events of Outer Wilds was mind-blowing (If you will allow a game to blow your mind) and changed my opinion of what the exploration genre can be. I recommend this game, even at full price.

My game of the year 2020.  If you like space exploration and self-led problem solving, you will absolutely love this game.  Try not to read anything about it, because it's at its best when you go in as blind as possible.
