Right. First off, if you get a couple of hours in and you hate this game with as much of a spluttering vehemence as I did, then go and have something to eat (I had a pizza and watched the Moomins), and come back at stop trying to get  on with the woeful controller controls, and just use m&k instead. The whole game feels like a complete chore on the controller that they so highly recommend on the startup screen, and honestly it's not like m&k is even messy. I hated every second I played because the clunky controller scheme is just not my bag at all (devs plz add invert x-axis, there are dozens of us. DOZENS!)  Changing controls changed my entire perception of the game. It was no longer tedious going back to the place I'd just been to and died at, because I wasn't dicking around and blowing myself up trying to land, and I was actually making gradual progress, exactly the kind of progress you're MEANT to make in this game. When tedium is replaced by some even small modicum of success, it all stops being a chore and starts being very moreish. It's like an interstellar tube of Pringles¬Æ (Pringles give me free stuff). I'm not sold on it being "the game of a generation" that some people are touting it as, but I'm only 3 hours in and I guess I'm just glad everyone has stopped banging on about the Witcher 3.   At the minute I'm not looking forwards to what I think is about to happen gameplay wise, but I absolutely will be driven by the story to complete the journey, although I dread to imagine how many passes I'm going to have to make in some areas (I have enough problems with brambles elsewhere. Don't ask.)  From a technical stand point, I'm not sure why my (admittedly 3 year old, but it's still rocking a 1060 so it's hardly a sack of potatoes) Razer¬Æ (Razer give me free stuff) was lagging. Seemed to clear up a little after a while, so maybe it was a background process causing problems, but I had to drop off some settings to get it to stop janking about like a janky thing (which was also killing me at times), and I can run much more visually demanding stuff with no bother.  Oh and devs maybe add crouch. My ship fell off a cliff and I couldn't get low enough to get back in so I had to go do a self murder
I didn't truly understand the physics of space and the universe until playing this game.

This sounds like the kind of game I should really like. Open world, very different, well conceived in style. But I just don't get it. I'm 18 hours in now and only have the vaguest ideas of what's going on. The problem I have is that the 22 minute reset absolutely punishes any kind of pace at which you can really absorb anything. I find myself feverishly clicking through texts, hoping that the ships computer will record the salient points, with the constant worry that I'll just miss the last text before the reset and I'll have to do the whole lot again! I've a few other major issues that I'll not mention as they contain spoilers. I'm utterly bored with it at the moment and the only incentive to finish is not to waste the 18 odd invested hours thus far. That's the only interest; nothing more nothing less. It could be that I've been playing the game 'wrongly', and that I need advice on how to play it. But if so, the game has failed on a very fundamental level. The main spirit of the game seems to be around open world exploration and a world into which you are deliberately dropped with no explanation. External guides and tips should not be necessary. Since writing this review, I thought I'd give it another hour and see if it could redeem itself.... It couldn't. My playing experience is so antithetical to the reviews, I'm wondering if they're genuine.

There isn't much to be said that hasn't been said in other reviews, but there is very little about this game to dislike. Sure, the spaceship can be a little tough to pilot, but the way the game allows you to explore and discover the entire universe at your own pace, and in your own order, is fun. I'm not going to spoil anything, but this game had more "woah" moments, where I found myself taking some time to take in what I had just seen/discovered. The only type of person I wouldn't recommend this to is someone who needs action in their games at all times. If that's not you, you owe it to yourself to play this game.

This is a game about how the Universe will inevitably die.  Everybody will die. Your friends will die. You will die. And nevertheless life still manages to be beautiful.   Maybe even meaningful?  To be precise, you will die a lot. As an intriguing mix of the movie [i]Groundhog Day[/i] and every childhood's astronaut phantasies, the game's setting tosses you out into a sandbox-like miniature solar system caught in a time loop, where you as a member of the Hearthian race leave your tiny, cozy village to follow the footsteps of the pioneers before you into the dangerous Outer Wilds. You will be able to explore anything your eyes lay their gaze on (& your flimsy junk-ship can hopefully reach)... until the sun goes supernova. Yes, this [i]will[/i] happen - in 22 minutes, to be precise - and you will be there to stare at the chilling view. Until that happens, you are free to choose what to do with your free time. Welcome to Existential Crisis - [i]Outer Wilds[/i] edition.   The game has a lot to offer in this regard, and quite rarely was the author of this text instilled with such primal fears and such amazement in such a short span of time in a game. Apart of the inescapability of your glorious death, the fear of the vast, dark void surrounding you (and even [i]approaching[/i] you - Black Holes, anyone?) is only the main of a long list of ticks the developers aim for troubling the animalistic brain part of yours with.  The planets follow the laws of Newtonian physics (with a touch of quanta), and you yourself will abide them while visiting every celestial body and synthetic anomaly you become aware of. As time flows onward (even though it will soon reset), all locations change and evolve, and places you just visited may be unaccessible in a few minutes or don't even exist anymore, and vice versa.  This fact is important, as the aimless wonder about the cosmos around you is soon to be replaced by a mystery tale about alien precursors, which visited your planets thousands of years ago. If you wish to uncover the secrets lying behind the source of the time loop - and not roast marshmallows at a fireplace on the moon next door, listening to the happy tunes of fellow Hearthian's instruments while the Universe revolves around you (you can do both, to be honest) - you will need to plan accordingly where and when to go. With your rust-bucket of a spaceship, or without.  It's a tale about death, inevitability & loss. It's also a story about love, companionship and the unending wish and strive of living beings to explore, to create, to do good & to [i]pass it on[/i]. In this sense [i]Outer Wilds[/i] isn't only an adventure spaceship simulator, but also a sweet-bitter, beautiful experience of a lifetime.  Who knows, maybe life [i]really is[/i] meaningful after all?
Easily one of the top 5 games i've played, ever.

One of the most fascinating and terrifying experiences I've ever had with a game. Savour every moment of your journey, dear Traveler. I wish I could forget everything so I can experience it for the first time again.

Mit einem eigenen Mini-Raumschiff d√ºst man in Schwerelosigkeit zwischen unbekannten und einzigartig kreativen Planeten hin und her (mit so mysteri√∂sen Namen wie "Glutzwilling" und "Schwarzdorn"). Jeder Winkel des atmosph√§rischen Mini-Sonnensystems hat √úberraschungen parat, und mit den gesammelten Indizien erschlie√üt man sich schwer zug√§ngliche Orte und l√ºftet nach und nach die gro√üen Geheimnisse. Das ist das Spannende: Das einzige, das sich sammeln l√§sst, ist Wissen! Unbedingt immer zweimal umschauen (und geduldig sein), bevor man was √ºbersieht! Outer Wilds kombiniert das Beste aus mehreren Welten: - Entdeckungswahn von Subnautica - R√§tselelemente von Portal - Zeitschleife von "T√§glich gr√º√üt das Murmeltier" (also kein Problem, wenn man mal wieder zu stark beschleunigt hat und mit voller Wucht irgendwo gegenkracht - es geht wieder von vorne los!) This game is easily one of my all-time favourites. It does a terrific job of encouraging your curiosity to explore a magnificently crafted solar system. The story unfolds in a nonlinear fashion, but manages to be compelling and clever nonetheless. There are only a few puzzles in the game, but they are all well designed and very satisfying to solve. And most importantly, Outer Wilds is a masterful use of its medium - no book or movie could give you the same experience.  If by some strange chance you're reading this review while trying to decide whether or not to buy the game, then I implore you: Please stop reading reviews and just buy it. The game is worth every cent, and the less you know going in, the better your experience will be.
Do not spoil yourself on this one. Don't even type the name into google until you've finished it

I can't exactly tell what it is that draws me into this game. The graphics are the perfectly done to make it feel inviting and silly, but the story is so totally compelling... The problem solving is incredibly well done, and all of the mechanics mesh so well. The soundtrack is also very pleasing and really something to behold. If you don't get motion-sickness, this is a must-grab, because it's totally stellar and I'd recommend it to any and everyone.
Little to no replay value. No combat. Incredible environments. If you like Subnautica or have a passion for archeology/anthropology(zenology?) this is a must play.

Incredible game - absolutely loved it. I encountered a few small glitches that were slightly annoying but they were completely overshadowed by how amazing this game is overall. The overall atmosphere and story-telling are great, the puzzles are well crafted... just an excellent experience overall.

Not for everyone! When I read that this was an exploration and puzzle game, I was expecting something completely different than what I got.    I love the design, the setup, the world, and the atmosphere, but the actual gameplay is incredibly stressful (something I usually don't say about exploration/puzzle games...). I'd been hoping for a relaxing and immersive exploration game with traditional puzzles, but the puzzles in this are more like "make it to this exact spot at this planet at exactly 5 minutes in or your route will be blocked." And with the somewhat clunky controls for the spaceship, it makes it that much harder to be at an exact spot at an exact time.  There's no time to really take in the scenery or the cool worlds because you're constantly just trying not to die/close yourself off under extreme pressure.  Missed a single jump in a long platforming sequence? You're dead and have to restart.  Autopilot screwed up? You're dead and have to restart. Spent too much time on a planet? You are now trapped and will soon be dead and have to restart.  Didn't land the spaceship the right way? You're dead and have to restart.  Ended up in a spot on a planet 30 seconds too late? You're dead and have to restart.   There's never a feeling of accomplishment when you DO get through any of these events because you just know that 30 seconds later you'll trip up on something else and die, and then you're back at square 1 with nothing to show for it, having to rush to make the journey back all over again. To make it worse, the game doesn't even save things like text you've decoded on walls (which just looks like meaningless swirls until you read it), so you find yourself re-reading the same text over and over again because the game doesn't make any indication that you've read it on a previous timeloop. All the game developers would've had to do is make the swirls a different color once read, but they chose not to do this and a lot of other things that would've made players' lives a lot easier. The ONLY thing preserved from loop to loop is your ship's log, which just contains a lot of vague and inscrutable clues.   The most important thing to me in a game is that I'm having fun, and it's just not fun at all for me when an exploration game actively tries to thwart my attempts to explore at every step of the way, with a crazy sense of urgency and very little room for error.
It's charming, it's tricky, and it's got a few fun twists.  Certainly a gem in the rough.

One of the most enjoyable and unique puzzle games out there today. It's hard to make too many comparisons without spoiling things, but the key aspect is that the world itself is the puzzle, and your goal is to learn about it. The more you learn and piece together, the more places you figure out how to go. It's kind of a space archaeology adventure/mystery. You will likely have no clue what you're "supposed to" be doing (other than learning) until the very moment that you know everything about what you need to do. If you ever intend to play it--and you should--you should try to go into it with as little information as possible.

Some things can only be experienced through the medium video games provide. This game explores the human condition with that in mind. This is a work of art that cannot be replicated. Truly unique, genuine, and beautiful; you can feel the effort and passion poured into this game.   Honestly, it's quite inspiring. Thank you Mobius Digital!
excellent game, cool story, it felt like a journey.

What a masterpiece.  I really didn't expect such a fullfilling journey when i bought this game on sale. All the positive reviews are justified. Just go in blind and enjoy the experience. You won't regret it

Outer Wilds is terrifying, but in a good way. So many sci fi games and stories always tells of adventure, wonder and excitement but Outer Wilds? Outer Wilds is real with you, it does not suger coat anything, at every turn it reminds you just how dangerous and ruthless space actually is. Sufficating, crushing and so, so empty. You are no chosen one protagonist out to save the universe, you are one guy at the mercy of the cosmos it self.  And I find that beautiful.  To brave the most inhospitible wastelands and celestial bodies on a journey to discover the ancient secrets of the galaxy, and to uncover the tragic end of the forerunner species that came before you, whose structures litter the very solar system you inhabit.  It by all acounts a journey of a lifetime.

Sekiro seems pretty overrated and way overhyped to me. This game and Bloodborne are hailed as the crowning jewel by the FromSoft community but I just don't get it. It's one of those games where it's cool to watch someone else play it but its pretty miserable when you're actually playing.   Game is pretty clunky with prompts such as the rope dart or ledge grabbing not being responsive or just not really appearing even though it should.   The game is obviously designed to make you learn boss and enemy patterns by making a lot of attempts but it punishes dying much more severely compared to other Souls-like games by making you immediately lose half of your currency and XP with no opportunity to recover it which I find to be a baffling decision.   You're also forced to go through certain areas again or kill surrounding enemies before attempting a boss/mini-boss every time you die to them so it got repetitive very fast for me.   Enemies are also crazy fast in this game compared to you and the majority of attacks in this game are just a matter of how fast can you press RB, or how fast can your monitor refresh, or are-you-younger-than-30-and-thus-can-react-more-quickly .  Perhaps I just didn't play long enough to "git-gud" or see it as "another Miyazaki masterpiece" but I'm glad I managed to get a refund at 2 hours and 58 minutes before I got to the more annoying parts of the game and can spend my $30 elsewhere.

There's a reason this game has a dedicated community that does "no-hit runs" on the daily. Best combat I've ever experienced in any game period. Of all the fromsoft games, this is hands down my favorite.   The story can be a tad confusing at times but at least its more relevant to the player's actions than Elden Ring or Dark Souls.   It's a real shame that the DLC never really came into fruition, and that completion of the "mortal journey" (the game's hardest challenge) has no achievement or rewards associated with it. Its rough performing the hardest challenge on one of the hardest games in the world and not being able to ever prove that you did it.  "Hesistation is defeat." - Isshin Ashina

Pros:  Storyline is great and the world is fun to explore Cons:  Borrows heavily from FTL but without the depth or nuance.  For example, one of the best way to earn resources is to explore planets on the ground.  This relies heavily on the stats of one of your officers.  The problem is you do not know what skills the planet needs to be successful and you just kind of move through a series of events automatically.  It doesn't feel interactive or strategic at all.  Either you are lucky enough to have the right skills or you aren't. Weapons do not have the variety that FTL did and the squadrons you use in battle all feel the same for the most part even though they have rock paper scissors mechanics.  Bottom line: It is still fun to play and worth buying.  It is just such a shame because it could have been so much more.
So far I'm enjoying this FTL-like game. The battleship-to-battleship combat is very different, but you get used to it. Dev team seems responsive to player concerns, which is always a good thing.
Fantastic game.  Great fun with plenty of replay value.
Outstanding and Relaxing Rogue-like, with plenty of moments where you need to lean into the seat some more.

Similar to FTL but with a much more story focused bent, Crying Suns is a great tactical rogue-lite game in a dark sci-fi universe where the right choice is never clear cut.  The story is really the strongest draw of this game and every bit of text tells you more about the slowly decaying fallen empire you find yourself attempting to save.

It's a souped-up version of FTL.  It takes some minor getting used to but after a while you'll pick up the flow of combat.  Free tip: Impaler cruisers, if you can find them, really help with ships that have hardened hulls, but can't fight on the field proper.

I keep it short.  Its good, got a nice story too, but the story is a double edged blade here. Its a FTL like game where you go from sector to sector in a roguelite fashion, but since its story focused it will lose at replayability with repeating events. But its worth one lenghtly playthrough.

Edit:  The update was pretty cool. There is now a lot of agency in choosing which encounters you face with which officers, deciding which routes to take on the star map, and the combat seems to have a lot more depth than the original rock-paper-scissors I remember.  Around chapter 4, the story got very interesting for me. I recommend this game on sale -----------------------------  There doesn't feel like there's actually a lot of agency in this game. Most of the interaction events are a yes/no check on skills that officers carry. Not a lot of interaction there for a game touting story. I'm at the end of Chapter 2 and the story is really underwhelming thus far.   Combat is interesting at first but quickly becomes repetitive, it tries to bring RTS into the mix but it falls really short because again- no agency. Your options and abilities to deal with the various threats that ships present you are incredibly limited by the scarcity of the campaign and RNG of what rewards you receive.   The combat revolves around drones your main ship sends out, and these smaller units are set up in 3 classes with a Rock/Paper/Scissors style of balance. This is probably the worst design choice of this game. After the initial ship choice, you don't really have the ability to alter strategy or unit composition, as resources are limited and you cannot construct or repair your own drones.  The rogue-like portion of the game is also rather lacking in agency. You can randomly find events to upgrade your officers, allowing you unique combat abilities and extra dialogue skills... but since you can't choose your own, this is also heavily RNG based. There's nothing to actually do outside of combat either except for click repeatedly and hope for good RNG.  Outside of the combat, which would be nice if you could alter unit class on the fly, this is inferior to FTL in almost every way due to the lack of actual control you get over the game. You're just clicking through dialogue, dying, and restarting until you get good RNG or have memorized the event results (they do not seem to have multiple results- each event will occur the exact same way every time).

Roughly comparable to FTL, but with much better story. Tactics do not evolve around manning ship rooms but around defeating enemies in a space fight. Use your ships and guns to destroy the enemy capital ship before it gets you. The sectors are generated randomly with anomalies, stations and planets to look through, just like in FTL but it seems to me winning a game doesn't relay as much on luck. Definitely recommend this game, I have much fun with it, although I just completed the first chapter (of seemingly 5).

Great little game.  A small learning curve in the beginning, but after that it goes very quickly.  I guess I must have enjoyed it as I played it for 73 hours in the first two weeks, lol
It's like a more polished version of FTL.
Hat bei mir FTL als regelm√§√üigen Zeitvertreib abgel√∂st. Cooles Gameplay, coole Story, cooles Setting. Leider noch ein paar BUGs, durch die schnelle Ladezeit aber hinnehmbar. 4/5
A great story with awesome strategy gameplay.

As a roguelike and space combat simulator, it's fun. The story structure and chapter setup keeps you interested and offers up at least the illusion of replay value. Once you get through the story, however, and start trying to get into harder and harder runs, I would describe the rng as borderline impossible, even for this genre. Often, boss fights will include 2x as many squadrons as the game indicates the other battleship has, and even more often then that, your run won't have even offered up the choice of getting the tools you needed.  The random events throughout the galaxy are fun and interesting to start, but the 'bench' is incredibly shallow for these things and after 6-7 runs you've seen every single one and know which to bother with, which to just skip, which to only go for if you have the upgrade to win every 'coin toss'. All in all an incredibly cool game with solid mechanics that just doesn't offer the kind of replayability you'd expect from a roguelike.
If you enjoy the planning and chance of rouge-likes, then this is for you.

Awesome hidden gem! Hits all the right marks for a space exploration game with a deep setting and totally works. No dice throws for ability check but instead a solid abilities system for ship and crew. resource management (money, power, damage, crew ect.) is really well balanced.  You're always watching out but rarely feel overwhelmed.

Many games claim to be inspired by the likes of FTL, but few actually manage to do its legacy justice like Alt Shift's Crying Suns.   Full review at [url=http://www.geeksundergrace.com/gaming/review-crying-suns/]Geeks Under Grace[/url]
It's incredibly addicting and fun! Like FTL with a better story line.
A new spin on the FTL formula. Worth it.

Great game!  It's a little repetitive towards the end but the gameplay is a lot of fun! There are a variety of viable tactics and strategies once you get into how the mechanics work.  [spoiler]The story starts of incredibly although it gets a little bleak or antihuman towards the end. There may be multiple endings I don't know about and maybe in better playthroughs they're optional. Great story telling regardless.[/spoiler]  Thanks for making a great game! I look forward to subsequent playthroughs as the other ship types and on higher difficulties.

Crying suns is not a bad game, but it's not, by far, as good as FTL. Just finished the story (normal difficulty) and thought I'd share. Is it fair to compare them ? I don't know, but I just don't see how not to.  Graphics are nice, when there is something to look at, which is often not. It's quite simple to sum up :  travel animation : great !  10ish actual cinematics : awesome (guess one needs a trailer to its game) space : empty tactical fights : oh god the emptyness Story is good and I like the grimdark tone and various twists, its what kept me in. Otherwise the games is very, very thin. Not very challenging, Not very original. Just not enough to discover. I did only one staight run, never failing once, and still managed to encouter the same event again and again. If you like this kind of game, go play FTL. Even the vanilla one is much better.

In my personal experience, love of games typically stems from 2 things: experiencing a fulfilling, challenging story OR experiencing control on a level that doesn't apply to your life (just look at the popularity of simulators). Usually a combo of the two. However, sometimes, the greater art is actually being restricted from god-tier control, yet still simulating a realistic role of leadership. Crying Suns (great name btw) is an absolutely stunning Admiral simulator RTS roguelike FTL-lite.   The jumping beacons and targeting baddies is unfortunately immortalized by FTL, but is a great mechanic executed well here. But in the end...you are an admiral of a battleship. You can tell where your planes go, you can tell your cannons what to target, but you are the admiral. You watch your men die because of your decisions. You don't point the literal gun. That is one element of the storytelling that is done so well here. It helps you feel like your decisions will trigger things beyond your control, and yet you have to forge on.  Cons: Restarting every sector with the same gear and weapons and squads available is truly a grind. The novelty wore off pretty quickly. It is straight up obnoxious when looking at replayability. Plus, while the ships are interesting, there is an acute lack of battleship to battleship combat (which would be cool), and each ship is basically hyper specialized in one or two types of formations of squadrons and weapons to use, meaning you will always be relying on a similar build/rng for 6 sectors.  Aside from that, the visual style of this game is unbelievably good. It's in the tiny details, the way the screen rotates around a systems sun, the way light bounces off your crew's faces on the bridge...incredible. I love the pixel art. Just buy it to enjoy the art. But seriously, great game. Events and battles are a touch repetitive, but your enemies loadouts demand multiple thought out strategies from you, and you're forced to learn. New content is coming out as well, so cheers!

As noted by others it's a spiritual successor to FTL in its gameplay, with suped-up graphics and a few degrees more of customization. Really though it's just a fun game, easy to pass time with or really invest in. While gameplay can be somewhat repetitive - especially the deeper in you go - there is enough variation in enemy play styles to require modular strategizing. What works for one enemy won't work for another; enemy weapon/squadron loadouts require you to plan carefully your own.  Worth your time.
I absolutely love this game. Great story, interesting roguelite mechanics, and absolutely stunning atmosphere and graphics. My favorite game of 2019!

It sounds so good, that you might as well buy the soundtrack while you're at it. Of course, you don't have to, but if you love the soundtrack, you should.  I recommend buying this game if you love games like FTL or other space ship games.

If you are the type of player that plays these games all the way to completion, and you CARE about a satisfying conclusion to the story, Then stop. The ending is intentionally meaningless. There is no catharsis. It just feels like you wasted all the time it took to get there. It would have been BETTER if you never had the last conversation and just chose which achievement to add.  If you AREN'T the type of player that is going to grind away at the game to finish it, then sure, it's pretty fun for a while. You will notice that nearly ALL reviews only have a few hours of playtime. And most of the thorough positive reviews don't have the achievement for beating the game. The game play itself is fun, but the last  bit of story, and the ending will ruin it for you if you care about that sort of thing.  EDIT: Anomalie254 I'm deleting your recent posts because personal attacks have no place here. (though you will notice I kept the one that actually had commentary. Even if I disagree with you because you don't seem to understand the argument I and others are making.)  Further, I never claimed to want a HAPPY ending. I said I wanted catharsis. Failure would be fine. An outright BAD ending would have been fine.  The "ending" we got didn't just invalidate our character. It invalidated US. The players [spoiler] The Omni pulled the strings on everything for so long that everything happened exactly as they willed. "It would happen eventually." The player character, and the PLAYER don't matter.[/spoiler] And that just doesn't mesh with the core idea of a video game (agency).  This sort of writing would be fine in some obscure art game. One that is meant to be subversive. Or one meant to intentionally be unpalatable. But even one of THOSE titles is supposed to eventually lead to catharsis. Even if the catharsis comes from the player/viewer learning something.  This game is CLEARLY not that type of game. It was MEANT to be played by an audience. I'm unsure if the writing was just rushed and unfinished, or if it is just bad, but the ending is just...poor.

Having a blast playing Crying Suns! The game is reminiscent to old strategy games similar to M.U.L.E. but with battle play. The battles are swift and challenging. The ability to send a squad down to a planet and retrieve resources also make the game fun to play. I have played for a few hours and really am having a blast. Highly recommend it!

[h1]Crying Suns is excellent.[/h1]  It has an intriguing story about a fallen empire, fun, tactical and fast-paced gameplay that keeps you on your toes, and some of the most beautiful pixel graphics I have seen. Gameplay-wise there's a good variety of random events, several different unlockable ships and characters, and a lot of achivements to unlock. You will also have a lot of story to uncover as you progress, and over multiple playthroughs (with an interesting and innovative way of uncovering it).  Do you like games like FTL: Faster Than Light? Then I highly recommend you get this game. If you want to try it out before purchasing, they also have a [b]free[/b] demo!

This is a very good game. It clearly draws a lot of inspiration from FTL. One thing I think this game does very well is immersion into the role of the admiral. The entire game is from the perspective of you as the admiral on the bridge giving commands to your crew. The UI and game world are fantastic. I enjoy the tactical ship battles and the resource management going across the star map is really fun.  I do have a minor criticism in that at some points. It does use certain story tropes that I don't like and the random events seem to run out sooner than I'd like. After a few chapters I found myself repeating the same events and knowing the exact outcome of all the decisions. I think either more events or more random outcomes from events could benefit in this area.

If you liked FTL or other rogue-lite/like games like it, you will enjoy this.  There's much greater depth in the story and enviroment as well.  The fact you can retry over and over is even cleverly explained in universe.

I backed this at Kickstarter, and it's got a great style both visually and aurally. The game play has a nice variety and is nuanced, while offering choice, tactics and an evolving story. Too easy to die though, and I need to get back to it.

"While on a public server, I met a man named Depressed. Me, a friend of mine, and him began to have a very mature chat about losing hope in the world... I hope he'll get better, and if he's reading this, hi! It's Retro!  On another, somebody accused me of murder when I was already dead."  In Among Us, you play as a very fancy B E A N trying to fix everything except for your marriage. Along the way, 9 other players will be doing the same thing. On the good ruleset, 2 of these beans are secretly infected with SPACE COVID, and will be trying to ruthelessly kill everyone else. It's the good, mask-wearing B E A N's job to find these imposters and fling them into space, or just DO YOUR TASKS ALREADY, PHIL! GOD DA- Along the way, you'll meet such lovely people as: where, who, self reporting, smooth brained individuals, funny personalities [my personal favorite is Daddy], and losing the game because Phil wouldn't go to the reactor room with you DESPITE THE FACT THAT WE KNEW THE OTHER PERSON WAS INNOCENT MY GO-  9/10. It's amazing with friends, great online [unless you're wifi doesn't want to work], and will always give you a great story. At the same time, bad groups always exist. Just hope you don't stumble into one of those, and you'll have a blast!

Pros; Big nostalgia hit, plays so much like it used to do. Incredible campaign Great multiplayer Fantastic customisation NO MICROTRANSACTIONS Grind is easier than it was on the 360 Can mod in halo reach!!  Cons: No forge mode in it yet (modded only) Progression system is linear now as opposed to being able to choose which armour to invest credits in UI isnt as good as it was in halo reach 360 Can't see each others spartans in lobbies Only gain XP for multiplayer, none for campaign or custom games ( I don't know about firefight )  9/10 so close to the greatness that was Halo Reach on Xbox 360, but the changes they have made to UI and progression have for the most part been for the worse. Better graphics and being able to play my favourite game of all time again though are more than worth the $10

A few issues I have: *Some Audio Issues *Cant remap voice and text communications *Crouch is like how it was on the 360 for Halo reach, you have to stop before you can crouch *I hate Halo reach's Bloom Air effect. *EDIT: Also I have to re-apply my Native resolution every single time I launch. Buddy has the same issue...   Other than that, It runs very well.  5120-1440@120FPS very smooth. FOV of 103.  Keyboard and Mouse aim feels sooo good. I have been done with controllers for years and I am so Happy I can play Halo again and not need one.  NOTE: I did play this on the Microsoft Store before I bought it here. I put in about 12 hours on that before I switched to Steam. I just much prefer this platform even though I got it with Game Pass.  Thank you Microsoft for not fucking us so Hard this time around. Halo reach is the worst Halo made by Bungie, so it's still a good game, yet not as good as the previous ones.  However, 343 industries might be one of the single most incompetent bunch around. The menus are terrible, the social part of the game has been completly butchered and they ruined the customisation by streamlining the progression system.  As for the game itself, well the campaign is the worst out of all the halos up to the 4th installment. It does start off great but just falls appart, failing to instill any sense of urgency to the player. Also, there isnt a single lovable character. The spawns in multiplayer are laughable, and the footsteps barely make any sound, which sucks for SWAT for instance. Why would i hear someone mouth breathing like crazy, but i wouldnt hear them running in their 2000kg armor? As for the ingame stats, well i've never seen someone fail THAT hard at making stats. Pretty much everything's wrong. Is it so hard to track? Even my KD's wrong. How can you fail a KD ratio?  For 10 bucks, it's a steal, that's the only reason i'm recommending it. 40 euros for 6 games, 3 beeing among the top fps games of all time, well it's completly worth. Even if they completly failed the "social" part of the game.  Edit 17/03:  Halo CE: The campaign is a masterpiece. The story, the music, the layout of the missions, the AI, it's simply in another realm of videogaming. Far better than Reach. However, the multiplayer has aged and, in my opinion, is barely enjoyable. I could blame the maps, the weapons and whatnot, but what really is the problem for me, is simply the lack of recoil when you get shot. It makes the whole experience bland. And no nostalgia helmet's gonna help with that. Also, there barely are any players on the game right now. Thanks to a lack of any actual events by 343, and a rushed release of Halo CE. Still, again, for 10 bucks, it's a steal. Also, 343 adressed a few of the problems (allowing rebinds for the mic key), yet too many are still in the game (crashes for instance).  Edit 14/05:  Halo 2. God damn does the campaign disappoint. My memories of the game were fuzzy, but i remember having a bitter taste in my mouth. Mostly because it was on pc and i had to use a 3rd party exe to play on xp, but now i remember. There's just too much waiting time, the weapons feel odd (especially the shotgun), the floods are insanely strong, the ally one shot you melee, the checkpoints are random. Compared to Halo CE, it's just a completly different experience, and in my opinion a lesser one. I've not played the multiplayer yet, but i dont think it's gonna be on par with H3 or Halo Reach. As for the port itself, well it's bad, as expected. Bugs, poor performance, crashes, and atrocious decisions taken regarding the UI, you know, the usual for 343. However, the remaster in itself is surprisingly good. The original game's esthetically bland, with washed up colours,  lack of majestic environnements, it's overall disapointing compared to CE. And the remaster version is the exact opposite: it's colourful, lively, and grand. The cutscenes are simply jaw-dropping. There's nothing more to say, it's just beyond amazing. So, the port's bad, the remaster's good, the base game is worse than i remember, overall, it's meh. I wish i could find my nostalgia googles, but it seems they dont fit anymore.  edit: 10/08 Halo 3: For some the best game of all time, and it's not even close. It's not my case. Althought  I have to admit the game still holds up very well, even to this day, it's not on par with Mass Effect 2 for instance. The campaign is just great. It scratches the "two playable characters" part from Halo 2 which in my opinion was poorly implemented (every single of the arbiter mission was bad) and focuses back on the Master Chief. A great choice. While the dialogues have clearly lowered in quality, the momentum, the energy, the set pieces, everything else has jumped to a completly new level compared to Halo 2 and I'd say, it almost reaches Halo CE level of quality. As if that wasnt enough, the multiplayer is simply amazing. Just like it was back in the days. It honestly didnt age one bit and the change of medium doesnt really affect it too much..... Now now, not everything's good in the Halo universe. Why? Microsoft. Those money hungry bastards keep pushing out half-baked games to get them all out before the release of their latest shitbox and their flagship game Halo Infinite. So we get bugs. We get awful hit-reg. We get lazy skins and lazy challenges. We get buggy achievements. And it's heartbreaking. It's heartbreaking because, for once, 343 isnt doing such a terrible job. Granted it's a simple port to PC and pretty much everything they have added is either buggy or bad (the UI is one of the worst i've ever seen), they are actually trying to do it the right way. It's just sad that they took so long to start working on these ports and are now compelled to release them plagued with bug.  edit: 28/10  ODST is completly different from a regular Halo game. The ambiance is completly different, and so is the tone of the game. The gameplay, while at the core similar to the main games, has been tweeked to fit more to an ODST soldier than it would a spartan. The soundtrack is amazing and, again, very different from what we are used to in Halo although some of the tracks in Halo CE had the same moody feeling. I've got a few grips with ODST though: first off, it's far too short. Yes, it introduced the firefight gamemode but still, it's far too short. I didnt even try to get it, and still got the achievement for completing the game on legendary in less than 3 hours. Secondly, the characters. What they did pretty well in Halo Reach, they failed here completly. Although independtly from each other those characters are decent (well, we dont rly know much about them but at least they arent obnoxious), the way they interact with each other feels like it's been written by a 12 year old. I'm not saying the other games are better in that regard, but since in the other games the characters dont really interact outside of cutscenes, one cant really see the lack of depth in their relations. Thirdly, and it's my personal opinion, i did not like the way the arenas were built. I know those were made with the fact that we play as an ODST in mind, but it lacks variety. And so do the enemies. Most missions were too easy. And since the game's so short, well it doesnt really help if I can clear most missions on legendary on my first try.... Lastly, the last mission.... if you're going to force me into letting an AI do the heavy lifting, at least make it so that AI doesnt suck ass. I dont wanna spoil.... however god damn, if this guy's the best soldier Dare's ever seen, it's no wonder humanity lost. I woulnt call ODST weak, it's just different. And for 5‚Ç¨, it's completly worth the money. If i remember correctly, it was 40‚Ç¨ on release which is a LOT for barely 4 hours of gameplay on a regular playthrough on heroic... first try.  final edit 04/06 Halo 4 : The black sheep. The step-brother from another mother. It's not AS bad as i remembered, but it's still pretty bad. I wont dwell on it, but it just lost all the magic that made the Halo series unique. What Reach started, Halo 4 finished. It's the kind of game that makes you think "damn, why cant they just move on instead of milking the franchise for money". Very bad points : spartan ops. Legendary solo, it's one of the worst experience i've had on a video game. It's on par with trying to get sub 20 minutes on Regret or Gravemind. The prometheans. One, if not THE, of the worst faction i've ever had the misfortune to play against. The dialogues. Trash. Absolute trash. I'd almost go as far as telling you to simply skip the cutscenes. Good points : from a technical standpoint, it's pretty good. The soundtrack's decent too. I really, really like how the UNSC weapons sound, it has a lot more "hmph" and I think it's a good thing.

Changed my review:  This is Halo. You will have an excellent time playing the campaigns of these games, and the multiplayer is stellar. All of the games hold up reasonably well by today's standards. As far as I'm aware, a myriad of fixes have also been made to improve the experience as time has gone by.  If you're a solo player and want to try Halo on PC, then by all means. You won't regret it.  BBBBbUUuuuT....  The multiplayer is also filled with garbage cosmetics and skins that are, in my opinion, disrespectful to the original artists and developers of the game. Some of them do not fit or were clearly made for other games. I get it, it's to encourage people to play more but it is gross. Yes, I can disable it, but that's depressing to have to do.  Additionally, personal opinions aside, Halo 2 co-op is downright unplayable. Do not even bother. Your experience will be riddled with constant crashes that force you to start again from the beginning of the mission. I really tried to overcome this, following snake oil advice from the internet, but it was too much. Don't use MCC on PC for this.  Additionally, another complaint about Halo 2 multiplayer - cutscenes are cut off slightly before they've actually ended, which took me out of it a little bit. A minor complaint but it's still there.  TL;DR: Solo? Do it. Co-op? Consider other means for Halo 2. PvP multiplayer? Enjoy crappy cosmetics.

I love this game for nostalgia, so take my review with a grain of salt, but holy shit is it good. The story is crispy, and it really makes spartans feel more like humans than killing machines. Its like the main series is UNSC propoganda and this is reality. The multiplayer is fast paced, fun and refined Halo action. It has some annoyances, like sprint being an armor ability, but its a good system. The customization is incredible, and my friends and I have spent hours devising weird gamemodes to try out, like invisible flying hammer-people vs falcon. Once forge comes out this will get even better. The theatre mode is just fun. You go back to any game you played and get a gods-eye view on the whole thing, flying around watching or taking a different perspective. It also lets you figure out just how the hell you got killed.  Overall I love this game, it was a huge part of my childhood and I'm so glad that it's come to PC.

343's management of Halo Reach is poor at best, and in some cases insulting.  The critical components of this game that made it so memorable have either been not included in the PC release, or have been tampered with and are worse than original. It feels like we have the body of the game but it has no soul.  Cons:  1. Forge is missing. The ability to create a custom map and game mode, which could be shared and played with friends is gone.  2. Ranking up is no longer difficult. What once felt like an accomplishment has devolved into meaningless symbols next to the player tag.  3. Armor is now unlocked by a season/battle pass system. Which is strange because there is no battle pass. The system is linear and the player can no longer control which piece of kit they are saving for. The choice between buying a helmet, chest rig, shoulder pad, etc... has been replaced with a system that forces you to unlock gear you may not even care about. It's a bland and pointless system to cater to people who wish to put in limited effort to have the best gear. Not only was the armor unlock system changed to a tasteless, confusing, and uninspiring mess... The order of which gear was rare and difficult to earn in the original game has been scrambled with minimal thought.  4. Daily and weekly challenges are missing. Earning the big credit reward for completing a week long challenge in Halo Reach was awesome. They helped push the player towards the unlock they have been fighting to earn and the game feels empty without it.  5. Players in matchmaking no longer have the ability to vote for the next map/mode. This means less popular maps are played more often than fan favorites.   Pros:   1. The game feels fantastic on my mouse and keyboard. (Feels like Halo!) 2. 343 didn't tamper with the campaign or firefight. It seems original. 3. Custom key binding is allowed and is working 4. The original armor variants, logo's, and emblems remain original for PC. Yes you can remake your old clan symbol and tag!  5. The game runs in 4K and is well optimized.  Conclusion: For a positive review 343 should have...... Simply released Halo Reach in the exact condition it was in on Xbox 360. With of course the ability to run the game in 4K as we now enjoy. For bonus points 343 could have.....  Removed the objects placed limit from Forge and add the ability to forge custom maps for Firefight.

Some enemies may be tough to identify their weaknesses before it becomes too late (Mostly in the Sementary and against Mulua) 3. There are some misspellings and wording issues.   [b]Conclusion:[/b] Siluman Fantasy serves as a solid erotic RPG with great monster girl art in both character design and sex scenes. The implementation of an in game gallery is great for viewing the sex scenes or to rebattle a specific boss. First and foremost, a key for this visual novel was provided by the developer, and this review is associated with the "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31748181/]Anime Tiddies Connoisseur[/url]" Steam Curator group.  [h1]Review:[/h1]  Sometimes, when a game's developers sell DLC, it's a major hint as to what the game itself will be like. For some games, it's additional locations and characters, because they want you engrossed in a narrative. For others, it's level-ups and OP equipment, because they'd rather profit from a broken difficulty curve than make the game fun for all audiences. And for [i]Siluman Fantasy -First Half-[/i], its main add-ons are artbooks and stories. So even before you begin, you can safely assume that this game has a lot of well-made art assets, and it does! ...But sadly, this is the only reason to play it. Well, that and Dark Souls memes.  There are some sexy RPGs that continue to be interesting during its narrative, combat, and/or exploration portions, but this is not one of them. The story is worse than "Dark Souls with Sex", because it removes interesting lore and replaces it with either "lol this is a game" jokes or puns about sex. It's not an Action RPG with dodge rolls and sun-praising like Dark Souls; it's turn-based combat, like most RPG Maker games, but with a gimmick of constantly spending a turn to change your equipment and take advantage of elemental weaknesses (which is itself confusing, mainly because even completely ordinary-looking gear like a pickaxe or pike might have an elemental trait that makes an enemy immune to it). And the various areas to explore are littered with instant-death "Git Gud M8" (that's an actual death quote) traps, such as pits or deep rivers, which can make looking for items a frustrating experience. It's nice that you can at least adjust battle difficulty from an in-game gallery at any time...but since said gallery has most (if not all) boss monster sex scenes unlocked from the get-go, what's the point in playing at all, aside from a few achievements? I guess there's the memes (in fact, at the start, you can choose to disable the sex and play just for the memes), but the Dark Souls jokes get repeated far too often to stay funny. This might be a nice game to look at, but playing it simply isn't fun.  [h1]Summary:[/h1]  Uncut NSFW: Yes, no external patches needed. Can choose to see basically all of it directly from the Gallery after the tutorial, rather than playing the game.  [table]   [tr]   [td]Pros[/td]   [td]Cons[/td]   [/tr]   [tr]   [td] [list] [*]Excellent Art [*]Plenty of Sex Scenes [*]Achievements [/list][/td]   [td] [list] [*]Too many Memes [*]Tedious to Play [*]Unoriginal [/list][/td]   [/tr] [/table]  [h1]Conclusion:[/h1]  5/10. Playable, and has some nice-looking parts, but the "gameplay" parts gets boring too fast. It'd be better off if people could just buy the artbooks, rather than have a mediocre game attached to them. YOU Git Gud, Game.

+ Pros: Drawn characters are o.k.  - Cons: Gameplay: Not fun! You have to switch gear inside a battle to do damage. Items: No consequent progress. Some new items you get are worse then the items you already have. Then you get something better. Then something worse again. Gallery: Will not get completed, even when you see a scene, it doesn't get added to your collection. Conversation: To curse and beeing an arrogant pervert are the "normal" text-options. Bad paths: It exists hidden paths with no hints: Bad game-design. Curruption: The debug-room destroys your game. It is not deactivated and still accessible. -> Bad decision.  Bottom line: I'm not a native english-speaker and there are many misspellings in the conversations. It was done to give a NPC some kind of character. My opinion: It should be done with a good story and not with different kind of misspellings. Switching gear was no fun and a game should never let the player inside a debugging room. I don't recommend this game at all.

Let's start off with, I would not have purchased this game for myself if it hadn't been free. Secondly, the developer has asked me for an honest opinion, so that's what you'll find below.  Funds raised by this game will be used to make more games like it, and hire additional artists.   The good: - The H artist has done a good job. If you're into monster girls the game has a gallery where you can skip most of the content and get straight to the juicy bits. - This is their first game release, most RPGMaker users don't even get this far. For a small team of 2, this is a big accomplishment. - Always-run is active, so your character moves quickly. - The music isn't terrible. - Some scripts / effects were used which set it apart from the very bland default RPGMaker games, but much more could have been done. - Teleportation / fast travel through the fires.  The bad: - Most of the dialogue begs to be skipped, and has a lot of linguistic issues. This is a common issue with most H games. - Level design is large, narrow, and feels rushed and unpolished. - The sound effects feel loud by default and out of place. (default sound set from RPGMaker was likely used) - Default tilesets were used. This isn't "bad", but without parallaxing most of the game looks like a dime in a dozen. - A debug level was left in the gallery,  - No visible save mechanic. (game likely auto saves)  In conclusion, if you're looking for a good RPG game, this unfortunately isn't it. The beginning is there, and with time and effort a future version may be worth getting for a decent discount.  The 2D artist has focused on the H scenes and has some obvious skill, so if that's what you're looking for, you may want to check it out. If you're unsatisfied with what you paid for it, you can always get a refund after all.

(Disclaimer: I know one of the people who worked on this game and got a review key from them.)  Siluman Fantasy wants to be the Dark Souls of eroRPGs, but it ends up just being the Lords of the Fallen. It's an original English language RPGMaker ero-RPG, quite heavily inspired by both Dark Souls and Monster Girl Quest.  The mechanics are both the best and worst part of Siluman Fantasy - it manages to distinguish itself from the typical eroRPG by having somewhat interesting combat, especially on the higher difficulties. It's still somewhat limited by the eroRPG standard of only getting to use one character, but equipping the right weapons (which can be changed during battle) and using consumable items is required to win on the higher difficulties. Unfortunately, the mechanics are also the worst part, because it was a very buggy game that was being constantly patched all the way up to launch, and taking a single wrong step into water or a chasm will instantly kill you, costing you your hard-earned money and sending you back to the last "lustfire" you saved at.  The story is also unusually bad for an ero game. Most of the writing - as in, almost everything except the ero scenes - is reminiscent of an edgy early-2000s rom hack, with half of the dialogue boxes letting you shout the F word in response for no reason. Aside from that, the plot is also fairly vague and delivered in drips and drabs, much as you'd expect from something trying to channel Dark Souls.  For most people who will be interested in this, the sex scenes with the various monsters will be the draw. Almost all of them are femdom, in line with Monster Girl Quest, which was clearly one of the inspirations for Siluman Fantasy, and they're all at least passably written and decently drawn, without the random swearing and nonsense of the rest of the plot. They're fairly uncommon, though, since almost all of them are only shown when you lose to a boss, and there's only eight or so bosses in the entire game. (There's at least one sidequest with, as far as I know, the only non-femdom scene in the game as a reward.)  I don't think the gameplay is good enough to carry the game, and the plot definitely isn't. The eroscenes are likely the most enjoyable part, but be warned that even on the easiest difficulty, you still have to put some effort into completing the game. At least you can watch all the ero scenes from an in-game gallery, though? In any case, I weakly recommend Siluman Fantasy to monster girl femdom fans.
Sketchbook, not actually R18. Contains some of the early ideas behind Siluman Fantasy, if you're interested in that.

R18 sketchbook that's only loosely related to the game except for presenting some monster girl designs, but everything in this is in Codex Libido: Halloween, which is in full color, so I wouldn't recommend purchasing this.
